element_texts.text: Completed

Page 1st
Bangor May 2d 1839
Dear Mother, Brothers, Sister,
When I got home from school to day, I perceived a pr. of shoes being by the door which looked as if they would fit me pretty well, so the girl told me that a man left them for me, a little while before. Well after supper, Charles came in, he gave me a rale good letter! I went down town with him. I did not hardly have time to speak to him was not with him half an hour hardly.
Ergo, I now sit down to answer your letters, as I had nothing written when C. was here, and did not have time to tell him 1/2 as Joe said. First, I guess that there is not much danger of my hurting my health to work as I am used to it and good for it "to boot." As for work I guess I am to work as early in the morn as you are. Play, caught not fish! Lambs, I was not there to take care of them. As for jobs all I have done is to split up a little wood for C. Harris, next neighbor, about 1 1/2 hours. Mr. W and I had a talk about board etc. last week and he concluded that as he had go the stump price bush hole as Joe says, that he should have enough for me to do, to pay for my board spell at least. I get up between 4 & 4 1/2, make fire, milk & go out to work 5, breakfast 7 or little after. It does not per diem agree with me very well to work so long before breakfast. I don't go out at noon, or after breakfast commonly 3 or 4  hours. I take care cow, get water, wood, do errand, et cetera besides etc etc. So I study most of the time at noon, in eve, and morn sometimes. I get along well in Virgil, Algebra, &c. I have not caepit Greek yet as there is no class and I could not get along do anything alone.
Completed

Page 3d
I saw Mrs. Parker the other day, she is not expected
to live but a short time, she appeared glad to see me.
I sent her love to you, said she should not see you again
in this world, but hoped to in another.  She has
been sick for 4 months of a Consumption.  Old
Mrs. Harlow is well.
[upside down]Maybe got a bad cold. Is it not cold
As to the article Dress, first Caput, my head
is pretty well off, only, it want, a good find Palm Leaf
hat before long.  Second, my old stock is most
worn out, it never was well made, it seems as
if two thirds of the hair has come out.  I shall want a new one
or a handkerchief or something before summer is out
Then, my coat, it would have been 10 percent better if
I had half the old jacket at first, it is 'lucky' it come before
I begun upon the stumps.  The old jacket will last all
summer to work in, I guess; but my coat is beginning
to mean some, besides looking spotted, it begins.
A good many of the boys wear cotton (linen) jackets
and if one of those old thin coats could be fixed up
or any thing else; so as to be decent to wear to
school, it would be saving favor to my coat, and much
more more comfortable besides, the frock coat is a 
very decent garment, all only the pockets before
ever was, (at least that I ever saw) that had
them before.  As for pantaloons, it would seem
well enough.  If I had had some old ones before digging
the stumps, (although it would be a bother to
change them) but the dirty work is about done.
The Gallases haven't stretched any yet as I can see
I have more the Drab pants all lime most dirty work, but they look cleanest now
[left-hand side] 4 and ? How does this cold weath feel up there.
[upside down at top] all the dark colored Clothes are drefful to show dirt.
Completed

I don't know certain how soon His class will commence
the Greek.  In the school those that study Latin do not
Algebra et vice versa, they think they cannot attend
to both at once, I don't, Bangor boys is lazy
Recreations none, Companions none, Work see page 1's.
Vex. Trib. etc. Poh!  Progress and Improvement &c,&c;&c,&c,&c
Hurrah for Jackson!  How does the old barn look?  Good!
May day as I was digging up mine roots in the morn
I saw lots of fellows of both sexes struttin a maying
more than 50 went by me in one direction, they staid
until noon, but I guess few flowers.  School kept, but it
was rather think, though.  There was a great Fair ere at
the Bangor house, got up by the ladies  of St Johns
parish for the benefit of said Episcopal church
upside down Mrs. Ward at meeting today So I thought Sartin?
As for contentment you speak of, I am of a very page torn contented?
disposition I believe naturally so I guess there is
no danger - As to the family Mr. W is ? clever
I guess. Only he smokes his pipe half the time
in the house.  I shrewdly suspect that he is next to
a New Church, New Jerusalem, Swedenbourgite, or whatever;
he has lots of such books.  I expect he is
kinder wavering between two minds.  Mrs W is clever.
Joe. is a rail etener rouguish little bugger Baby 4ms
Mr. Wakefield is a clever sociable joking bachelor
lawyer, eats here, and sleeps in his office.  Said Lawyer
has always, something to say to every body, no matter
The girl has lately came. S.S. Teacher Mr. I forget about May 5th
I kicked the "Traffic" into the P.M. so often
I arrived.  I bought 8 sheets of paper lately - $. 08
[left-hand side] The wind Sat. made our stumps burn finely, ovfer?, cold morning.
Completed

Potatoes are $62 Eliab's was a very laconic epistle, he must not be discouraged, I shall expect quite a letter from him soon

The dark cloth of my frock coat is abominable to look dirty.  I have not had to write long.

I wish Joe send me a copy of one of his! save trouble!
Brownville                                                                                                                   Isaac Bangor
May 8                                                                                                                                  May 9, 1839

                                                          Mr. Charles W. Rich                   
                                                                                     Milo
                                                                                         Me.

[upside down] The vacation of the school is 4 weeks in August, I believe Mr. Worcester says there is nothing gained by beginning Greek to soon, the 2 languages puzzle one another, ? hindery?
Completed

This letter is small, but page torn, smighty?                       Bangor Maine May 12th 1839
Dear Folks, and Mother

                                                           I have not much to write, but as you said I must have a letter wrote all of the time beforehand; I can fix you to write if no more.

The ("stump hole") was ploughed last Wednesday P.M. with 2 horses and 2 men besides Mr. W. and myself! We have not commenced opperations upon it yet though. Mrs. W. cultivates this year a day bed in the shape of a garden 2 doors off from here.  I was ploughed a little, wed: but it is baked down miserable. I have to dig it up with a shovel; mix it in manure eten it is rather hard work. I have enough to do all of the time, out of School: more than pay for my board I guess rather
I work 4 or 5 hours per diem, none at noon though. I have wrote a letter to Ann, put it in the P.O. yesterday. When did you get my last letter and who brought it? I left it at Chase et. Henrys inn I am getting along some in my studies, about through 2 book of Aeneid. 40 to 60 lines per day. Have not had to speak or write yet being new scholars shall soon though.
Last Friday school did not keep, but the scholars got some trees and set out in the yard. I did not go for trees but remained to work in the yard, digging holes etc. The City Council furnished
Last Mon. Judges ? Cory? page torn and his wife Mrs. Worcester, Augusta, visiting, so there is a house full, now most. Mrs. W.'s regular girl went away sick April 21st since then I have had to milk. There was a little girl came and staid for 4 days and was homesick and Mrs. W. has done without a  anyone till last week, when Delia  came.
Mr. Tenney my S.S, teacher has left the school, gone to preaching up to the Corporation. last sabbath a stranger to day no teacher. Mr. Hatch has gone out of town, Vacation I dont know but it would have been well for Joseph to have left his cap here as he offered to; Hat, are not so much worn now as they used to be I guess; There is not a single one goes to the school. I have worn the Tarpawlin as yet mostly, but it will be to warm by and by, I guess I can get along if I have a Palm leaf. If I could have some kind of a green baise or white cotton or linen Jacket or frock to wear  to school it would be an excellent plan,  Save my Coat of which there is need as I have nothing else to wear to Church.

 The Brown Cloth is miserable stuff, always awful dirty. I have worn the Drab pants most of the time but they look neat and clean- the others are dirty, It has been very Smoky here for several days, hardly see the sun. Hant there been some cold at Milo lately, my fingers were cold mornings summat

[left-hand side] you nee not write on a half sheet, because See, I rally erry egg a cent! i.e. a sheet of paper.
Completed

I. M.M.
May 20th  

  Care of 
         Mr. Charles W. Rich
                       Milo
                           Me.

Mrs. Ann M. Metcalf

                 Milo 

[left-hand side]Potatoes are selling for 62 1/2 cents. Beans $2,50 Could not Charles bring down some Potatoes to sell? What do you eat? Charles bought any wheat yet?
LuLucy                      Lucy H. Metcalf
[right-hand side] How will you know who wrote this letter? I have got the globe up to Mr. W. Mr. Guansey said that the freight was not paid. I did not pay - untill the Chairs are taken away.   Guess again!
[bottom of page, upside down] 
Bangor  Isaac
May 12, 1839
Dear Brothers Joseph Mayo Metcalf et Eliab W. Metcalf 
Why don't you write to me Also Eliab especially
I want to and Must know all how you get along, and prosper. You Must write to me when you began to plough and where, to sow to plant etc. In short you between you two Must, write to me a full and particular account of each day's proceedings, every Minutae, when you planted, sowed, ploughed, harrowed or whatnot every single piece of land. Also about the gardens and everything else whatsoever; I will risque the paper, dont say anything about time; or any other excuse: there will be chances enough to send. Eliab's letter was rather brief, dont be discouraged, you must begin sometime. I shall expect a rail good letter from you soon Eliab I know you can write well enough to do it.
That Mr. Dunton (Writing Master) who came in the boat when you did Joseph is a going to open a school here soon, pr. $3, for 12 lessons. Mr. W. has a subscription paper. he (Dunton) is a most tearing? writer, there are a lot of specimens of his writing in P.O. Flourished off Greatly. Is not so. Lazy Eliab? Does he keep up his end of the yoke well? Who milks? How much do you get? I wish I had some Bread and milk. How high are the Early Peas have the Vines on the  ? page torn up? How do the horses stand it? What do you do with the ? page torn sum etc. etcetera. etc,
Completed

Beans $2.50                                                                                        Bangor Wed. May 22d 1839
Dear Folks                                                  Evening
Mother, Brothers and Sisters!
I have been to work all day, planting in the
field and sowing exculent roots in the garden
After supper, I went down town I found not
in the P.M but in the P.O a letter from Milo
Well! as you wrote of Charles bringing down some
Potatoes I thought I would write to stop him, As
Potatoes have suddenly fallen from on high
A few weeks ago the good Chenangos sold for
$,70 or even  ,75 per bush, any thing that was a 
potato ,50 a bu ,62 whites  Now Chenangoes for less than
,50 -,42 and no market for whites at all hardly no how
I had a letter wrote more than a week
ago, but nothing particular, and as I had no chance to send
It staid in my pocket till now.
I will extract from it same as I am in a great hurry
The Farm was ploughing May 8th by horses
not very well, Mr W has taken a clay
bed in the shape of a garden 2 doors south of here
it was ploughed some but I have to dig it up
with a shovel principally, hard work rather
I put a letter for Ann in the P.O May 11th
Judge Cory and his wife Mrs. W Sister Mercy
May 6th visiting with 2 young uns - went
away 15th  Mr Hatch has left town Vacation
My school teacher has left, gone to preach to
the Corporation.  Mr Dunston, W.M
who come in the boat with Joe is teaching
W.S. $3 for 12 lessons &c &c &c
It's after 9 now so I can't stop to write mud
You Must all Write
Joe Write 10 times more particular about
all of the work.  Every thing is selling
at Auction here    What a letter
I had written a good one so full that I could not
luck in the Praties. Och!
Completed

Isaac Bangor
May 22 39

                                                                   Half Sheet
                                                     Mr. Charles W. Rich
                                                                              Milo
                                                                                     Me.

23d

                              I am getting along inchy? shrazy?3 book ?
                                           You Must Write Better
                                       I am awful Sleepy
Completed

Bangor Sunday May 26th 1839

My Dear Mother

                Brothers and Sister
                                      One and all; Greeting
                                I dont know what you thought of my last letter or rather - several - I dont know what - but you see, I went down to the P.O. just at night, and got a letter from home, containing among things information that Charles intended bringing down Potatoes. I immediately set to inquiring concerning the market for pratoes and judged it expedient or rather necessary to write by the next morn mail. I did not get home toll towards 9, then had to write a letter, half a days work,  and get up very early to put it in the mail, too. - Excuse etc.

The principal news now is - that I am going to leave Mr. Worcester's. How so? you ask, I suppose; Well. Mrs. W.'s last summer's boarder Mr. Albert Paine came back here to board a little while ago Well, Mr. John B. Hill had spoke to Mr. W.  last winter about boarding here and little more than a week ago he came wanted to come immediately, and would take my denial. I suppose Mr. W. thought it would be more profitable to have per week and do his chores himself and hire his work done
So as Mr. John B. wanted a chamber I had to quit. Mr. W. said he was very sorry that I could not stay all summer, that it would have been very convenient for him etc., but I suppose Mrs. W. was opposed to my coming at first as it would be no help to her and make some work etc.  I dont now certain where I shall go certain on account of Mrs. Parker's state. Mr. Wm. Abbot C.S.S.C. talked of wanting a boy only his wife is now not at home, but said if I could not find any other place he would see about it. both would be excellent places. Mrs. Parker is very feeble indeed cannot remain long.
Mr. Worcester is from N.H. is a nephew of Noah and Sammel Worcester. He says it is a very bad plan to study to hard, said he went through Graeca Minerva in 3 month and 11 days, reviewed it, reviewed it in a fortnight etc. studied 18 hours per day, (not moderately either I guess) but said he lost a great deal by it, I was sick almost a year, and now I cant study over 6 hours per day with profit. It is Vacation at the Seminary Mrs. Hatch is gone out of town. Mr. Willy, Wiley or whatever is going to open a Singing school next Wed. for Youth people Terms $,50 for 3 months every Wed. and Sat. P.M. - Cheap.

I should like to see; your bundle for me, I need the Stock; Lute is a rale good gall, only I see she has not got over her silliness. Why did I not hear from Eliab in the last letter? I expect quite a letter from him, he was rather laconic in the previous one. Your letters are not half particular enough. I want to know every thing. Presavve your ? page torn Joe. Poor old hat.

Our Peas came up last Wed., have yours? Cucumbers? Flower garden? Have you no butter to bring send down? ,25cts. It is a pity Charles could not have brought some potatoes at, 62 1/2 some time ago, May 1st.
Mrs. W. has 12 chickens about ? old, how many you got? does the farrow turkey prosper? also pigs, calves etc. etc. etc. etc.?
It seems to me that you Folks are slack or amiss about writing
Completed

Joseph M. Metcalf

                           Mr. Charles W. Rich
                                           Milo 
                                               Me

[upside down]  Mrs. Anna M. Metcalf
[right-hand side] I have had bad sore eyes more than a week but I believe they are getting over it first a little sore in the corner. then I hurt them studying while they were sore Mr. W. has a farm, 4 acres, out a little, I work on it Wed. et Sat.
[Bottom of page, upside down] The Brown boys have got summer Jackets? page torn, thing looks Sattinett, or something, just as tight ?page torn ? with high velvet collars done round the neck. Palm leaf hats are now much numbered?
Teus. May 28th At Asa Walkers, I moved here last night. I am to work in the garden, do chores etc. I think I have got an excellent place. Mr. W. appears to be a very pleasant man. [next line is folded and torn--only words decipherable] a young man, who is studying law with him, a very pleasant clever fellow. Mr. Walker prays in his family. belongs to Mr. Pomroys church. his cow gives 14 qts. of milk per day, have bread and milk to eat, his corn, beans, peas, turnips, potatoes etc. are up and growing. Mr. W. is close by the school-house, right across uncle Nats garden. I have got to speak tomorrow and write Sat. dont the grass grow. Charles waggon has been standing in C. et H. yard, all day. I have only been able to learn that 2 men came in it and went to Stillwater. Why did they not bring my bundle spose? We have got most of Aeneid. Mrs. Parker is very feeble indeed, not expected to live for great while. Mr. Walker's sister does the work here now. A Mrs. Dutton is also here. She used to be acquainted with you, she says.
I cant see why you dont all of you write more, better, particularly, etc. James Walker is rale clever young man I guess. 30th What a rain! I am going to put this in the waggon box and see if it will get home, as the waggon yet remains here. and I dont who come in it or where to goe find them.
May 26  39
Isaac Bangor
Completed

Bangor Monday June 17th 1839

Dear Folks
Unc, et Omne!
I am now laboring under no ordinary
calamity, Alas! my pen; my pen!  Vats to be done now?
To explain, I went out Sat. and bought me six 
steel pens with a rale cute mahogany hornde? for the round
sum of 30 copper cents, paid in good silver coins!
Well yesterday I left it on the mantel, in our room, at
night.  to day noon I wanted it and behold it was not there!
Neither in the room:  I mentioned the loss to the folks, and
little Alba, who had swept out the room in the morning,
thinking herself implicated, made a most diligent search
for it, but all in vain, it is not to be found upon the premises.
The most profitable opinion is that Miss. Walker carried
it out with the dirty clothes, and it fell or was lost.
I have bought a cloth cap for $1,25, wish I
had done it two months ago.  It is a real good one, worth two
of Josephs,most. It will last me a good while, I guess
I guess I shall get along pretty decent for
Clothes now, only I ought to have a handsome summer
vest, but can do without pretty well I guess
The coat is rather large especially about the sleeves
and is much longer than they are worn now
Otherwise it is a very good garment for Sunday morn
It'll do justly well, I guess.  I shall get along for pantaloons
this summer, I guess pretty well.
Your letter, Dear Mother, was very excellent.
but rather too short, wasn't it?!
I guess I shall get along after a fashion at Composition.
I have, written but two yet, one a short and rather hurried
on upon the subject of Early Rising, the other a decentish
one upon the history of queen Dido, of whom we have
been reading some what in Virgil, lately.
Don't so much skeert at the copper I guess, I wear it
"That old thin coat" does pretty well I guess, I wear it
to school when it is warm, although it is so cold and rainy
most of the time nowadays that there is a fire
in the schoolroom, a good deal of the time
The new stock is excellent, rather too deep for me tho
there  Those collars or dickey, are much too long and too deep
too big and round instead of fitted? too fine too
I wear them or should if they were good ones to meeting sometimes.
Most Affectionately I.S. Metcalf
Completed

I feel rather dissatisfied with that are Joe's letter;
it is rather stingy, I really think:  it does not hardly atone
for his long silence, and most egregious defaultment.
I expected to receive from him him and Eliab as much as
3 or 4 sheets full of all manner of accounts, respecting
the business and affairs of the farm etc etc. instead of a 
miserable little half a sheet!!!!  I believe Eliab was the best
I should like to have seen your letter to E.L Barnes!
I do hereby greatly congratulate you upon your new or rather
old batteau to say nothing of the "slipt into the drink!' ha,! ha!
hide yer boat in the bushes!  Preserve ye one of
yer partriblth eggs, until that I do come unto you
Write me about the next etc:  Write me all about
the sheep shearing, the quantity of Wool etc. also all
about the number, quantity, quality, magnitude, species
and nature of your lands.  I think the Iron Mill
pasture is an excellent plan.
There is no need of sticking up letter in
thus and Heweys, now, as it is just about as near
or nearer for any one to go by Mr Walkers and
leave a packet as not only keep right down Centre
Street instead of Exchange.  First House above the
Baptist meeting house, same side of the road, where
the Lilacs and other double pink poseys do grow.
The Peonys and Columbine are now bloomed in
the front yard, also Adam and Eve, a large blue
flower as you got up to Mr Crosbys, last fall
Mr W. has lots of lilacs I don't know as there is
more at any place in town.  I propose transmitting,
to you a bunch of them, if a convenient season
I was greatly rejoiced at Eliabs letter it contain
the most news of any, I believe. Fire away
try it again, once a week.
Mr. Walkers peas began to flower Sat.  two blossoms
good on your head, namely your raft, Dive away
I should really like to help you swim this summ
I have been into the water but once this summer
that was Sat.  upside of the Railroad, in the woods
with James, while getting tadpoles, water 3 or 4 feet!
Hurrah for the de spikes of the old boat.  What about 
them are beans up river.  Tell us how the fire
prosper.  Take care of my farm!
Completed

A Touch of the Sublime

I rise, Mr. President, to argue the cause
of the poor man and the rich man, and I believe
that before I shall have concluded, you will all allow
that it is a case that does not admit of any argument
In the first place, Mr P. the rich man declines his emaciated
form on a rich mahogany sofa, cut down, hewn out, made
and manufactured from the tall Cedar of Lebanon, which
grow as you all know, on the lofty and cloud east symmetry?
of the ever memorable mountains of Jehoshaphat  Then, Mr
P he lifts to his endeavors up the golden china cup, made and
manufactured as you very well know in Chile; Peru and
other unknown and uninhabitable parts of the universe,
While on the contrary Mr P the poor man declines his
expectations in a cottage from which he retires to the side of some
umbrogous stream there to contemplate the vast
constellation and other fixed and immovable satellites
who devolve around the celestial axeltree of this
matter acqueous firmament on high.  And then, Mr. P.
he calls his wife and the rest of his little children
around him and teaches them to perspire to
scenes of immortality beyond the grave.
The foregoing was found by me in old Newspaper
and spoke in school last Wed. as I could find nothing
else.  As I had nothing particular to write hardly, I thought
I would send it for the peculiar instruction and
amusement of brothers Jo et Eliab.
And now I do verily declare that, if I having
nothing in the world to say, hardly, can write a whole
letter like this, it is an abominable shame for
that are paddy Joe et Bob, also to write me a letter
on a half sheet of paper (not half full neither/ behold
And that once a month  What I should so want
to know every thing about every thing.
3 sheets every week (Full)
I.S.M.
Completed

Friend Hatch has arrived.
I met him in the street last tonight.

 I expect he is rather impatient for his school money! often he has asked me when C. was down and would be again, he said he had better guessed, get his town order into the form of a note and send it up. that the town ought to have got the money before now etc.

Ill, give him the stockins prompt that will please him.

Mr. Charles W. Rich                  J.M. Metcalf
            Milo                                       Milo


Isaac Bangor
June 19, 1839
[upside down] You must all try to do better about writing. 
Tell me what the Balorahn? says about the Lilacs if they get there safe!
Wed. Morn. I have just rec. a letter from A. and the folks children and all are well. Lucy arrived safe and sound.
Sat. morn. Very fine passage, You ought to send me Anne's last letter had not you
Completed

Bangor Sissvieve? June 30

Dear Folks  omnes

                 This letter s for an Apology. I have written two letters to you already to day. My apology for this is that I cant spare time weekdays and there is a good deal of Sundays. the three meetings per day and S.S. do not take more than 5 hours, and I can not read all of the time.
 For the abominable appearance of the other letters I can pardon on the ground that, I happened to have a lot of half sheets etc. in which would not make compositions.! As for the miserability of the writing,  I would observe that, I took an old poor Goose quill because I could not write fast enough with a steel pen.
Instead of going to meeting house this P.M. I went to hear Mr. Weed, Temple Missionary, he calls himself. His temple is great and made without hand, being the open air
Completed

He preached this afternoon in a kind of grove up the Kenduskeag about half a mile or less. He is an old man, large, and very majestick or very good speaker, and round in his doctrines. I guess he is somewhat of a Methodist belief, there was a very large assembly, all sitting on the ground or standing, he preached 5 sermons in the course of the day, 2 A.M. 2 P.M. 1 evening. He thinks it wrong to spend so much money building churches, organs etc. My apology  for going to hear him, is that heard him in the morn. before meeting and liked him some etc.
   W began the VI Aeneid last week, shall begin the Greek grammar soon, this week I expect. We have got most towards through the Algebra, and gone back to review now. I have declined but 3 times, and wrote but 2c; it was my turn to write yesterday bit it was put off till next week. 

The trunk is just the thing I wanted
Completed

I dont know whether I had better have a new coat or not. The blue one is very large and long, but I spose I can get along with it. It shows very plain that it was not made for me. I wish that I had some kind of thin pantaloons to wear this summer. I guess I can get along without any new clothes, though. As for the Vacation it is not yet certainly decided when it will be it always has been in August, first Mon. I believe, but there has been some talk of changing it  this year into Sep. I guess though it ill be in august, the boys all want it then. I will be decided soon

Teus morn I saw a lot of teamsters come in just now and I can send this I guess. What shall I & 4  of day other?

                               Good bye etc.
                                    Affectionately
                                                                                           I.S.M.
Completed

Isaac Bangor
June 30 '39

                                          Omnes aut quisquam                      All or anyone
                                                           Milo
Completed

July 9

Dear Joseph

              you are truly a real good feller

you are an excellent brother to me

                   Just as I was going to school this morning, word came to me that a man wanted to see me at the door! I went and behold Mt. J. Hatchkins. he brought me a letter from you. You is a coot boy. Mr. e.c. ought to be ashamed you schold about "fault finding" but you must remember that I wrote that a long time ago, when you did not write.  one letter staid at C. et H. about a week before I -d it you know.

You have been an very excellent boy lately, but I have not heard from Mother or Eliab for some time.
I should like to see your E.C. Barnes letter!
I be greatly lament your fine boat, I had hoped to give in? I told ye to hide it in the bushes, why didn't you?
Go and steal it from him?
It is generally too bad, bad, Bad, Bad, BAD!
or Rope, Anchor, paddle, everything at all.
This is the way I make a J with a J a C this G to. [upside down here] Mothers
If it will plase ye I will make them better  the way it dont look so well though

 I has a very great hope to see you face to face, in a spell, it is so long since I only converse with you, that I have almost forgot how you look! not quite  good boy  

We are just commencing Greek now
I am a good mind to apologize to you for scolding so as you say! but I was got rather impatient you see, besides I had nothing else to write, hardly!
I have not had time to send your H. on P. though yet. I meant to have sent this yesterday but found no Chance. I guess this page looks! }out it} to
[written across letter] June 1839  Mr. Isaac S. Metcalf

                                                               Bangor
                                        At Mr. Asa Walker
Completed

Bangor Sat. Oct. 5th 1839

Dear Mater et soror

  Wed. night I saw Mr. N. Hatch jun. direct from Milo, who gave me two letters and umbrellas: you may be sure the letters were a nice feast after digging potatoes all the after noon. I have not sold the wood, and I dont see as I am likely to for $,50 per pound or any thing near it. I think it must be a mistake about wood selling at Exeter for $,60. Here - Nobody wants to buy wood. Woods "dont buy any wood now, and pay cash, at any price," he says. Lunt or Campbell and Mills "dont want wool,will take pelts." Larrabee will take pelts or wool, clean washed, (since sheared), but at nothing like 50 cents. I went all round Friday and enquired, although I was most ashamed to, I have been so many times before; but could get no encouragement. Meanwhile I have got but little more than $.50 and have not paid for coat yet entirely or got me either boots or Shoes. and I must (ought to) have a pr. of Gloves of some kind to wear to meeting, immediately etc. etc. etc. "Vats" to  be did?  I sez.

I want some Mittens right away, my hands are really uncomfortably cold this very Sat. morning, turning out the old cow!

 You will see that I am "check full" of wants, of all kinds, names and sizes; but I dont see how it can be helped.  I have been almost thinking, that it would be best, to go quit the field for the present and go home to work till I could be ready, and fixed (Where/when would it be?) but it would be rather a a pity now that I have got fairly begun and in for it; besides I should get very behind my class in Every thing and could not get up

[left-hand side] I am glad Charles went to the Cattle show etc. but Sorry for his work which I fear is behind hand.
[upside down at top of letter] I have got a bad cold at present. I guess I shall borrow a dollar or two of James F.W. and pay off Mr. Fox for I told him I thought I should get the money next week and next week has come a great while ago. I dont like to be in debt.
I suppose I had better send home the vest that Mr. Fox cut out of the coat cloth and have it made up at home I am sorry that the blue vest you made last summer was not double breasted.
[near Salutation] Write Often to me do.
Completed

You See, (If I stay here) I have to twice every day, go into a little dirty barn or stable, and milk an old cow, what's laid in that same old dirty stall, all night, besides taking care of her, two pigs and other dirty work. You will readily perceive that if this is done in the same clothes that I wear to school, that I shall continually be dirty, smell like stable etc. etc. etc. etc. James tell me I must have a regular butchers frock, (such as Charles used to have) and keep me neat and clean. James bothers me a great deal about how I shall get along this winter. (He is going off to keeping school, before long) He says---
Sun. 6th The shirt that you send - one of the shirts that I have got here is Josephs I guess for it is so small I cant wear it anyhow. wristbands about half big enough - very short, too. The pair of fine shirts (narrow collars) are most too thin and cold to wear in cold weather, and I hant got but one other one besides Hoe's. My shirts all labor under a mistake in making, - one for the collar, one too narrow -inconvenient  and dont keep my neck warm, and the vests are too narrow to turn over and too wide to not in the way etc. etc. however they all answer a pretty good purpose! ought to be about medium of those I have. I fear I shall want mittens much before I get them, and I must have also some kind of Gloves to wear to church etc.  I am afraid I shall be to cold this winter, it is cold here already, it is here than it is to home! surtin I want some Inkstand. I want some Suspenders. I want some Mittens, I want a Comforter, I want some Shoes, I want to go home. I want most Everything to say nothing of Pants, Jacket and everything else most. I guess you will think I want enough to make you crazy, and more than I shall be likely to get.

 I will try and do what I can about getting a Chance for Sister Ann. I dont think there will be a chance before Spring. At the beginning of a Quarter not any time would there be a chance for a Primary School I suppose, but that is not.

You must all of you wrote to me often/ &J.do            I.S.Metcalf
[right side] Isaac Oc 5 '39

                        Bangor
Completed

Bangor Sunday October 13th 1839            

   I am sure no one can say that I do not wrote home often enough. If I could hear from home half as often, I should think myself well off; I do not see why I cannot, especially  when I remember that there are four or five at home to write to me.
 I received a part of a letter,(half sheet) from Ann last Friday eve. by Mr. Walker, who said some one gave it to him in the Courthouse. If I had got it an hour or two sooner, I should have sent the wool right up by Mr. Cutts, who went out that night, as I do not not see any prospect of getting rid of it here.  But I could see no one to send it by yesterday: probably shall by Wed. or so.
   The letter if it is short contain'd news indeed, about Joseph going to Boston. I dont know hardly what to think about it, but should think it would be an excellent chance for him if he can get it, with Mr. Whipple. It would not  be $2.50 per week, besides his board, I suppose, would it? How soon will he goe if he does go? !! he will have a nice chance I guess,  should think so. Joe will be a Gentleman!  Well, I shall be glad to have one in the family. He must mind and be a good boy, thats all.
 I have not much of any thing to write about now, that is, if  you have got a letter I sent up last week by Wm. Porter. Wed. However I thought I would a little to send up with the wool!  I shall also send, I guess, that Shirt of Joseph's, (which was sent by mistake I suppose) that old stock that Lucy made, which has got so white, in spots, that it is not fit to wear! and some flower seeds, perhaps, that I have gathered here etc. I meant to have brought with me that other old stock, (the soft one, pocket or roll stock)
Completed

It is a pretty good one to near yet, and looks whole and nice, when on my neck, although it turns round rather easy.
I get along pretty decent well yet about clothes, except pants to wear to church, of which there is a great lack. My old frock coat holds out pretty well, does well enough to wear to school every day, only it is awful dirty, as I have to do all my work, most, with it on. Mr. Walker has lately, last week, got a new, cite and and excellent looking stove and set up it the, late dining room, now to be called the kitchen, he has also got a great Sink put up and has the aqueduct water come into the would be kitchen, Meanwhile the little, old kitchen is cast, off an goes to grass as a backroom.  This innovation has made a great change in the appearance of things, the old Fire frame is cast out, the fireplace, overhauled, and built up entirely with brick. The funnel goes right up stairs into the back entry, where is a large drum, as it is called, for the purpose of heating the chamber. It will make the chamber where I sleep most as warm as it is down stairs, so you see it will be nice about lodging evenings etc. I tried it last eve. the fire was kept in the stove, and I studied up stairs, it was nice and comfortable, mmmm, but it made my head ache I found. I fear it will be bad, at least Mr. W. has got some sticks to burn in the stove, it has to be sawed rather short, but it takes but very little wood. I wish you could see this stove it is real curious. all manner of fix. there is four places to put
pots or kettle or anything, two over the fire and two over the oven, which is large and behind the fire. The stove and appurtenances, lots of boilers, kettles, griddles, pans and every thing in money cost $
Completed

I want very much to hear, more particularly, all about how you get along etc.etc. to home. Joseph ought to write to me more about the work etc. Also ELIAB. All must write to me. 

 I dont suppose that there is any expectation that Charles will do anything on that lot up the river; this fall, is there? Ia?
 It appears to me that Charles is rather late about his work, is he not? I can not help wishing that I was there, sometimes, almost.
  Mon. Dont you think I have a knack of filling up a letter, by some means or other, when I have nothing at all to write?    
    I am in a great hurry to get to have some money, especially to pay Mr. Fox.  I dont see as it will do to wait till the wood can be sold or. I told Mr. Fox that I expected to have the money in a week or 2. I wish - I hope that my new pantaloons will set a little better than those I have now if it is a possible thing; those old, coarse one that you made while I was at Milo set a great deal better than any of the others; although they are nothing to brag off at all. I need some suspenders much, and I dont want to buy any here, if I had the means, for they would not be worth any thing hardly.
  Thurs. 17th I meant to have sent this before now but can find no one to send it by. School dont keep this A.M. The Episcopal Church is being dedicated. School left off before 10, but I staid a spell and got my P.M. lessons. There was an alarm of fire Just now but I guess it did not amount to much.  

Yesterday weeding carrots 9 bu. Beets 8 bu. 
I am in a great hurry to hear from you and also to receive - Also to know about Joseph's going to Boston etc.
Mr. Welch is down here now I believe and Mr. Weymaan to
Do write to me an tell me what to do etc. etc.
Completed

I feel rather ashamed of my last letter and also of this, complaining so much etc. I can get along very well now this long time.
I dont know as I ever shall want any more Shirts, fixed so cute too! I can get along about Boot or shoes pretty well for some time yet, only I dont know but Joseph will need that great thick Comforter I shall, if he was a going to stay at Milo. A little long one to keep on my neck all the time would be good for it.
[right-hand side]it is rather a pity to wear my High boots all out before winter comes. The Suspenders was in great want. Also the Gloves etc. More so.

                                                                                                 Isaac Bangor
                                                                                                          October 19, 1839
                            
                                                                                                                            Mrs. A.M. Metcalf     
                                                                                                                           care of
                                                                              Mr. Charles W. Rich
                                                                                               Milo

[ bottom of page, upside down]
Thurs. Morn. Since writing the last I have been down town to see Mr. Welch and happened to see I. Stubbs, who gave me a bundle from you. You may guess how soon I got home and opened it.

Did you take off the Wheel band to turn round

About Joseph bill was only some of my fun about his foolishness [struck out] It was only some of Joseph's silliness when I was at Milo, that I put in to fill it the letter. I am afraid you were more scared than I was hurt. I guess I shall get along pretty well after a fashion.
Completed

Bangor ? page torn eve. Nov. 3d 1839

[upside down at top] The boys have a notion of getting up an Ehhibition, at the close of this term, and will want me to help them about it, I expect. What it to be done about it I dont know how or what yet [[? Money or time or home what? or nothing?]]
Dear Mother and Sister etc.  

       I hope you have not quite forgotten me, but it is a good while since I received a real letter from Milo, the last was, I believe, from Joseph, about the middle of last month: I am afraid I shall not get along as well about letters now Joseph is gone. I really expected a good long letter when Charles came down. Charles got in here in the morning but I did not see him till after dinner, most 2, oclock, and just before he started for home. The 'Tremont' with the potatoes and all on board, started from here Teusday night or Wednesday morning, James recieved a letter 'or newspaper' from Mass. a few days since,

which informed him that a letter that he sent by Joseph had arrived there. So I concluded that Joseph had probably arrived safe, sometime!
Mr. Buckingham, the orientall traveller, has been lecturing here on the Holy Land, Syria etc. (you will remember extracts from his lecture published in the Mirror, last winter) At his introductory lecture, (free), the meeting here was 'chock full' standing up and all, and lots went away. The single tickets for the course were sold at $1,50 apeice, But the next day, (before the lectures commenced) Mr. Worcester recieved a note from Mr. B. informing him that his scholars might recieve tickets for ,50 the course, if their money forward through him Mr W. & Mr. B. himself. A very large number of the scholars, of whom I was one, accepted the proposition, and I have attended the lectures, although I dont know as I Ought to have spend the money. ? The Lectures were useful, and instructive, and very well attended, I believe. Mr. B. also gave a temperance lecture here. A committee off over 20, containing 5 ministers' (Mr. Pomroy), 2 Prof. Judges, Doctors, Representatives etc. was formed to express thanks and so forth.
[upside down] Eliab, how many more muskrats?  have you killed, especially Partridges?
Completed

I fear I have written one one one side of my letter pretty quick or not said much either! We have got through the Aeneid of Virgil and are now reviewing it at the rate of a book in 2 days, 3 books in a week, 3 books already. Review the Aeneid and read the Bucolics this term, next term Cicero.
This term is 14 weeks, consequently 5 weeks longer; Vacation 2 weeks. I should be at home at 'Thanksgiving' then, shall I? Greek gets along slowly.
I want much to know how Charles got along with his work now a days; I am sure if those Piles over east dont get burned off it will not be the fault of the season. I am afraid the ploughing will come out at the little end of the horn, if Charles had not begun when he was down; There could not be a better chance than this fall. Mr. Frock coat has one ragged elbow but I guess I can get it mended perhaps and it will answer yet with the aid of the other old one which I never ?wear I suppose I could possibly get along this term out with out only night shirts?  only 4 or 5 sabbaths more! I could get along after a fashion then?
[right-hand side]
Isaac Bangor
Nov. 3, 1839

                                                                                        Mrs. A.M. Metcalf
                                Per     C.W. Rich Esq. now I. Mitchell
                                                         Milo  Piscataquis
                                                                         Maine

Bangor Nov. 5th 
1839
[left-hand side] Monday
I guess if my new pants are cut after there last, coarse ones, they will do pretty well only the legs are too large and hardly long enough, body plenty large and long, James rec. a newspaper from brother Joe by mail today You must all write often and make Eliab, it will be good. Is it not unseasonably warm and dry, cisterns never so empty before. I forgot to tell Joseph that if he wanted to send a letter or newspaper to me to direct it to care of Asa Walker, then it would come into his box. I guess then at the end of the term I had better come home and go to school to sister Ann. Please write soon and much.
Completed

Bangor, Sunday, November 10th 1839

Dear Mother Sister et cetera   I received a letter and bundle from Milo yesternoon, per A. Walker's office.  Mr. Walker and James have both been gone most of this week, Mr. W. to Norridgewock and James to Hancock, where he is going to keep school this winter, they got back friday, So you see I have been the man of the house. The letter was excellent, but as far as the frock -- I guess it is no go -- I dont think I could wear it over my jacket or any other way hardly -- the sleeves are much to short and it is much to small round the neck and the whole upper part, round the arms too, while lower part is super abundantly larger. Marm? dont know how to cut out such a frock as that, I guess that the back of it must be cut in a separate peice, and very narrow at the bottom, whether or no something is the matter of this, it seem to pull right round somehow and towards the shoulders every way - can you tell how it suits me !! ha! I can get along about mittens till I come home, I guess. I need a pair of good, knit suspenders by and by. If you send any thing for me to sell, you must write how much they cost, are worth, or ought to sell for, cause I might get cheated, you know! I have got my coat mended etc. well.
As for a chance for Ann to set up a private school here, I dont hardly think it would succeed. For besides Mr. Turners high school, which is very popular and a publick select school for girls taught by Mr. Valentine, a Miss, I believe, and Mr. Crane, into one  ? your teacher have a select private school for young ladies, which is very popular, and attended by those too paid an assistant etc. to the public high schools. There are also very many common private schools seal over? schools (publick),  one under good management and in very good esteem generally. There is no matier? french teacher.  he now, I understand,  Mr. [blank] has been a popular private teacher here many years, but since the public high school was instituted and before he took the publick select schools, he had hardly any scholars at all, most none. I have not been to Mr. Abbot as yet, and I dont know as I had better till there is a vacant situation which we should want to secure, and then I dont know but it would be just as well to speak only to Mr. Walker. He suppose is sufficient. I should suppose from what Mr. W. says, that a situation as a primary school teacher, could be obtained by any person qualified out any of the vocations - most, especially by a good  --  but --
across letter You must write to me oftener all. I want to be home at Thanksgiving much what is to be done about it.
Completed

I dont know but I could, any most?, or a pinch yet clean through this term without jacket or frock. I want some woolen gloves, like Joe's, cost $,50 or so, but etc. I dont know but can get along this fall? without nothing at all, ?.?! I dont know but I should get about awfull as much good this winter to stay at home as to stay here and study Cicero and Greek Reader etc. to study and stay at home, under the tuition of Sister Ann. I guess Joseph growled a bit when he found his Journal did not come in the praties!  he will be disconsolate, I'm afraid.
As to composition, I dont hardly know about it, perhaps I might learn to compose nothing in a large time If I should study for 2 or 3 years, Parkers exercises in English Composition which by the way I very much need or at least want, if I rightly understand the subject.
Our class in the S. School has not had any regular teachers hardly for 2 or 3 weeks by but the new prof. at the seminary -- Smith from -- Mass. has agreed to teach I expect. The class consists of a lot of young men and some not very young. What has become of your Olive? I understand Joseph that she was there then. You did not write any of your letter Charles had got the Piles over east Bangor? You try not to have me think about the farm and much but I shall not be cheated into a lawyer yet I know!!! I will be a farmer after all the fuss, I guess.
[upside down and up side] I guess it would [[[puzzle]] a Philadelphia lawyer to read all of this letter, you will ?? to you ?? I guess.
[right side]  Isaac Bangor

                 Nov. 13, 1839

Bangor Nov. 13, 1839

                                                     Mrs. A.M.Metcalf
                                                                    Milo

[left-hand side] I dont know as you will be able to read all of this, but if you can not, it will be no matter, I guess.
Eliab must write me good, nice, long letters. It will be good for him. He lacks spelling, especially common words.
My coat is rather  ??   Write
