Bangor July 19th 1840  Sun.

Dear Mother and Brothers

  I know that I have been extremely remiss about writing lately, I guess that Ann has also, and I really think that you at home, both Mother and Joseph have not been very attentive to such matters this summer. I can hardly remember when we last heard from Milo, and then only little scraps or billets. On fact I do not know that I have received a real, good, oldfashioned letter, one whole sheet, during this term. Charles has been down here once or twice, but in such a hurry that I have had no time to talk to him. I want very much to know how every thing gets along nowadays, how Mother's health is this summer, how Charles' affairs look and prosper, how the Crops etc. are going to come in, which appears of some importance, even if they will sell for nothing; how the boys do and feel, work and play etc. etc. I most wish I was at home, whenever I think of it.
 Mr. Walker is doing great things this Summer. William A. Wingate, Housewright, with his Apprentice, Samuel Small, has been here to work most of the time since June 1st. and is not near done yet. The Painters have been here a good deal already, but have just begun. The House is to be new painted all over, inside and out, also the fences and barn etc. etc. etc. etc. I have been pretty busily employed most of the time out of School from July 3d, to July  13th, one week. I employed it principally at work for Mr. Walker, about the house etc. got to be quite a carpenter. Expect to be paid for it by him, dont know how much.  Worked pretty well, 13 hours per day.
 We have had a good deal of very hot, sultry, unhealthy weather here this summer. Such Weather is much worse here than a Milo, I think. Sweat 6 hours in the Schoolroom, go to work and Sweat, go to bed and lay awake and sweat; Hot, Sweaty, Tired, Sleepy, and foolish all the Time. Very poor time, weather, and Chance to Study much, at least to really learn much. James F.W. has been about 1/2 sick for sometime, a while ago, and alo is Sam, Small caprter.  And for 2 or 3 days past I have been most sick myself, neither worked or studied much. One awful hot day, got very hot indeed to work hard and then washing me in a hurry to go to School, cooled me so quick or something, that I caught cold I expect, and been not sick since
Completed

Mrs. A.M. Metcalf

                Milo
                      Me

[right side] Joseph is in a fuss for "them Compositions". I will send him some "Documents" to appease him a little. The Compositions are so very valuable, it wont do to trust them by the ordinary conveyances. I will brought um, when I comes, myself. Write to me as soon as possible to let me know if you are satisfied etc.
Isaac Bangor
July 1840 
[bottom of letter] Have had a very bad head ache, neck ache etc. My head feels as if it had too much blood in it for comfort, has for about 3 or 4 days last past. My hair has got very long, I dont know, but that is one reason of it, I have not got money enough to get my hair cut!!! What shall I do.
Tues. July 21st Brother Charles just called here, left a letter etc. Very glad to see it, indeed. I shall have to scold that Joe. though for not writing more, I dont know what his hand do, but his fingers are lazy, dont write. 
I have got about over my last serious and alarming illness, in the back of my neck. I staid at home all day Sunday, with my head as perpendicular, as you please. Yesterday Monday I went to school in the Forenoon. The room was very damp after the rain, caught more cold and had to come home before school was done, did not go in P.M. Took medicine, My neck has got pretty limber now. If I dont take more cold I shall be well enough soon. Guess I shall not go to school the A.M. though.
Completed

Bangor Sun. May 8th 1842

Dear Folks!     I had a letter written I was going to send by Charles, as I told you I most unfortunately lost it somehow or other. However there was no name to it any way, so if any one post it it will do them no good. By the way, I lost Lucy's beautifull excellent pen, I dont know how, when I first came here, Beg her pardon. Again there is no kind of a Table in our room, and no chance to wrote 'ceptin' on a book or so, without going down into the Reading room, 'mongst folk. Another time I dont ever have any time to write.
I dont know as it would be worth the while to write over again what I wrote before even if I could and could remember.

  Yesterday my economy be having been overcome Ann's arguments and et ceteras, I spent upwards of $8,00,  of which I almost repent already, some of it.
  I bought A Cloth Cap $1,50, a pr. of Drilling Shirts - for $1,50, A Ready Made Vest - $, 87 1/2, 1/2 Doz. of Linen Collars - $1,00. I had bought before an India rubber hat and a pr. of Suspenders etc.etc.etc. Oil cloth Jacket ?, 75  I have rec'd for my work but $6,75, as yet, about 9 Dollars more due. The Company, Cushing and Sheldon, that is just as good as gold, I suppose, & perfectly willing to pay all their hands in Cash. and do frequently when any one wants money for immediate use now, before work is done.

Sheldon has a store here and likes to pay the men out of that.  for the sake of selling goods, you know. So they say and I guess 'twas so I told Eldridge yesterday that I wanted some money & he gave me a 1.00 Bill and told me I might take up as I pleased at the Store, at Cash price, exactly.  I must have and got a Vest pattern $1,00 Silk handkerchief etc.,50 .

 Two men, Cushing  & Co of Frankfort and Sheldon of the Town? Kimball & Sheldon of N.York, both N. Yorkers, Kimball lives there and Sheldon here; have bought all the Logs in Kenduskeag to be delivered at Drummond Mill pond just above the City. The Sellers running them as far as there, doing the river driving. Our business is to take them there, turn then, out of the boom, over the Mill dam, down to the City, through 3 bridges, into our Boom, where we raft them together with a rigging, or rope, on wooden wedges. They are then run in the raft, to Cushing's to his mill in Frankfort, Sheldon's to Emerys Mill Hampden.  This is a Separate business, requires those who are
Completed

Pilots, i.e. acquainted with the river its various rocks, currents etc. etc. Cushings runners have 9/s per day.
Mr. Eldridge, our Foreman is a very fine man, I think, an old Sea Capt. or a Blacksmith of East Brewer.   He is a Temperance man and a member of Cong. Church.  The men all like him though they say he is 'straight as an H'!
Sheldon is a real clever looking little fellow, about as big as Eliab, and a very boyish look, though his face is covered with black whiskers!!!

 As for the work, I suppose it is pretty hard, at least it is so called, though I dont know as it is harder work than farming if folks work smart. I make out to get along very well with it. As for getting sick, there is no necessity for being alarmed. I have got a ducking several times, but I really believe it is a  benefit rather than otherwise, if one does not take cold, I think I have felt better for it, change my clothes a little, put on a dry woolen shirt.
  The worst thing is, the work makes me sleepy,  go to work at 5 P.M. and work till about Dark 7 1/2 or 8, if I want to go go to meeting, I feel so kinder tired and dull, I cant more than half hear or feel, if I dont actually get asleep. Terribly sleepy in Meeting this A.M.  I dont know but it is a retribution to me. 

How much I have, if not dozed away the time, minded every thing but the preaching in meeting. Now I want to hear.  I almost cant. I mean it bothers me.

  Wednesday Eve. Rec' a bundle brought  down by Mr. Coutts, very acceptable, Coat, Stockings & Shirts.  A very little peice of a Letter, better than none though. I do wish you would write good long letters, Mother, I dont think you write to your children as much as you used to, a few years ago. I suppose you have so much work to do. I hope Doctor will get married and take away the Baby, then when Lucy gets Smart, you must have a rest a Spell.
  Charles Wyman & Lady & 2 Children are here tonight, came in the boat. I have not spoken to him though. Franklin House is crowded, full, every night, 20 more boarders crowded into a poor room, 2 in a bed, Great mind to get a new  Boarding house. Old N. England is the Washingtonian House now.
Completed

I have read Lucy's letter to Ann and am rejoiced by it. I think I am really rejoiced to hear of Eliab's conversion. I have often felt Anxious about Eliab, even when I neither felt, cared, nor thought for my own soul
Deacon Brown of Brownville is down here now, to see about their lumber, I suppose, stay a week or 2. He boards here. He says there have been 40 or 40 hopeful conversions, east part or all in Milo, mentioned several. says that Charles appeared to be deeply interested. I do hope Charles will listen to the stirrings of the Holy Spirit.  Will give up his heart to the Lord. He has surely seen enough, to know the utter vanity of all worldly things. All that is required is just yeild, give up the heart to God. It seems as if now was, emphatically, the Accepted time of Salvation. I hope you will all pray for me, too, I know you do.
Wed. Eve.
Completed

Bangor Wed, eve. 27th

Dear Folks! 

                   I received your letter, to night by Mr. Coutts, very gladly. You do not say whether you rec; the bundle, concern that I sent last week by Russel Kittredge.
  The trunk came safe to hand, Friday, I believe it was although I did not see the one who brought it down. You sent down some dirty dickeys, I believe. It cost money here, washing, does. I lost the Bosom, I brought with me, took it off and put it in my pocket when I went to work, and somehow lost it out, I suppose, into the water.

I have just been up to see Ann, and got a letter she had written, and the money from Boston which has arrived at last, 70 Dollars, 
Herewith enclosed, 13 Bank of Bangor Bills, V.X.

                              Etc. Etc. Etc.
                                       Etc. Etc,
 You worry yourselves unnecessarily about me and my work, I guess. Mother thinks I am where I dont belong, I just begin to feel at home. It seemed a little odd at first, but come to get a little acquainted with the business and the folks it is considerably pleasant.

Mr. Eldridge or Aldridge, the Foreman, or Boss, or Old Man, is a very fine man indeed, I think, Very pleasant and so forth, but, straight as an H, as the  men say. He belongs over in Brewer, is a Temperance man and a Pious man. Cutler is a kind of a Sub, to him no control over the business and no responsibility. It is a Company concern, all the log owners on the Stream, Principally, Kimball and Sheldon, agents of a great N.E.? Co. and Cushings of Frankfort, Dinsmore's, Billington's, and every body else. Each drives his own logs to our Boom, up in Drummond Mill pond, just above the city, where the Co. through their agent, Aldridge, takes them, turn them over, as we want them, drive them down through the 3 bridges 
[upside down] This is OUR work
Completed

into our Boom, just below the lower bridge, in the stream, where we raft them, by means of small wooden wedges, driven into each log with an axe, and an immense quantity of rigging rigging, or small ropes, when each owner takes them and runs them to Hampden or Frankfort as they want them. 100 or 150 logs in a raft.

 It is a tall concern, there are 20000 logs in number to pass through our hands. We have 6 batteaux , cost 100, an tremendous quantity of rigging, large and smalls, one man furnishes 3 tons at 9 cts pr pound, 12 axes, pick poles innumerable 
   It is pretty hard work, I suppose, so called, but I get along very well with it, so far, at least.

I got one ducking, the other day, part of one, 2 or 3 have been in all over, Aron Hill got a real sousing one.

 I have been writing as long again as I intended and have wrote nothing either hardly I believe.
 I attend meeting constantly Sundays of course, and evening when I can get a chance. We work generally frequently when the tide favors till 8 o clock, sometimes till 9.

Isaac Apr. 27th 
1842
Bangor

                                                              Isaac April 27th
                                                                     1842
Completed

Exeter July 4th 1842

I do almost wish I was at Dover today; I suppose there are some folks there that I should like very well to see, shoud'nt wonder;
I am afraid the shower to day rather troubled some folks. There is a great meeting yesterday and to day in a grove, 4 or 5 miles from here west of this town on edge of Corinna. A new sect, Hambletonites, from an old Elder Hambleton who has some queer notions and new lights, and many followers. Lysander went up there yesterday; says there was more than thousand people there, and about every one got thoroughly soaked in the rain, some mud too. incalculable injury done to White dresses, and silk bonnets!
Mr. Cutler & I went down to the Meth. Quar. meeting in South Corinth or in Levant. The road is some miles on the line between 2 towns. The meeting was in a barn opposite Robinsons tavern; barn full, good many, Mr, Browning an Englishman, on this circuit this year
Completed

preached A.M. and the presiding Elder Nickerson, P.M. both pretty good, for Methodists. 6 or 8 miles, very pleasant ride but muddy.  Mr. C. showed me where a Dr. Gale used to live. A ruinoous & uninhabited, little old house, but on a very pleasant and highly cultivated ridge of land South west part of Corinth.
I suppose you lived there once Mother, did you not? 
Sunday before there was no meeting, except a Hambletonite one, up to farther end of nowhere. That day Mr. Cutler said there was quite a lot of Royalston folk together. 3 Messers. Jacobs were here Mrs. C's cousins, 2 just from Mass. One, Sumner is the Celebrated Thomsnian physician of Springfield Mass. not the old he one Isaac Jacobs, but perhaps full as tall. He used to be a leetle white headed chap round these mills, Went to Mass., 8 or 9 years ago, with nothing but his profession, a __ from Uncle Isaac, is now rich. Owns a great Establishment, 12 acres of land Cc, $7000, in Springfield Village, (10,000 Inhab.) Keeps 6 or 8 very tallest horses, practice extends over all the western part of Mass., from Worcester to N.Y. and Vt. states
Completed

Subdued prejudice, used up the Regulars, and got his name up, very highest round. Going to take his older brother, Ivor, back with him head servant to look after his farm or stable. 

  Mr. Cutler had a letter from Royalston lately.  his father is dead, also Luther Richardson and others that I neither know or remember.
   I like my work pretty well. It 'grees with me 'zactly to work nights; always felt best after Supper you know, and all night, never sleepy. Begin my days work at 5 P.M. or immediately thereafterin. (Supper leetle before 5. Breakfast little ?page torn dinner 12,) Go up to the house and eat at Midnight? Get done about 5 or 6, A.M. and go to bed, get up before noon? sometimes sooner if the Sun shines too hot on the roof!

P.M. till 5 Lazy, except hoe the garden etc. Dont work any Sat. or Sun. nights, but tend Sat. P.M. & Mon. A.M. 
I have sent down and go my trunk from Bangor, but I find that Charles has not been down, or at least has not been to the trunk, and I have no key to it! There are some things in it that I want & also some things at Milo. If some of you are not coming over here visiting before haying. I'd wish you would take immediate measures to send a bundle over here. This could be done by the Stage,
Completed

or, which would probably be the better way, I could easily get a bundle, directed to me, and left at the Franklin House.
Exeter ME  
July 4th /42  Exeter 
Mrs. Norma M. Metcalf  Milo Me
Completed

Exeter. Sabbath. Aug/ 7th. 1842

I expected to have received a letter from home last week but did not. I sent a letter a week ago last Wednesday, but am afraid you did not get it. as it was sent to the Post office by a private conveyance.
Its principal object was to find out whether you wanted me to come to Milo to help do the haying. I take it for granted you do not, or you would have sent or come after me before this time. Most people have got through haying, about here. & I guess I have to.

 I carded nights all the time 4 weeks, the fifth week three nights & three days, and last week I did Mr. Curler's haying, he having one or two hands to help me, while he and Lysander were occupied in the Shop. It took hold of me pretty hard at first. My hands had become so very soft & tender, working only in the oily ? of the Mill, that I blistered them before noon, mowing, quite badly, and they were some sore for a day or two. Besides this, perhaps I took a little cold. I kinder sore and stiff all over, for a day or two, when not sweating. However I worked it off, in three or four days, felt better than before, did not tired me to work a bit.

Monday, Man & boy to help me, mowed about all day, Tuesday, mowed in the forenoon and in the afternoon raked it all up 75 pretty large cocks, grass thin, ground rough.  Wednesday mowed in the morning, opened etc. all the hay. & Mr. Elijah Crane with his horse team helping got in 7 loads. He pitched on and I off. 5 loads ours, and 2 of his besides making up one load for him. 3 of us, besides Lysander raking after, P.M.  Pretty good days work, was it not? fifteen hundred at a load, at least.  In the afternoon I stick a pitchfork tine into my leg, just by the knee, considerable. after supper it began to be sore, swell up, lame, stiff when I went to bed it was much swelled all round the knee, very sore, hardly bend my leg at all, very lame, expected I had got to have a lame leg, perhaps be laid up for a spell. But (Mr. Cutler's folks are Thomsonians) I bandaged it in flannel with the miraculous Hot drops, rubbing some in well,  and truly wonderful to relate, it actually drew out the cold, took away the swelling and soreness and in the morning, my leg was about well !!!!!
I do actually believe, that, without its application, I should have had a lame leg.
Thursday I worked for Mr. Crane, for his work the day before.
Mr. Elijah Crane is a very fine man, very smart worker indeed in these parts,  but he has his hands full this year. Selectman, Sup. School. Corn. Administrator of Mr. Uphams estate, about which there is a good deal of fuss, building a new house, just like Mr. Cutlers, (2 carpenters all summer). a large farm and business to carry on, all himself.  but he is good for it, also his wife Julia Baker, used to be. This preceding is only a digression, for the purpose of introducing to your notice, his horse team,  He has a couple of small, round, tough little horses, valued at about 50 apeice. They have done all his farm work, hauled the stones for his cellar etc. no small riding round to boot, and been to Bangor in a  team 13 times, this summer, sleek and fat all the time, bright as a dollar. Would two like Pomp. do it? Horses are very low indeed, no market for them down east. If Pomp is sold this year, he will have to go to the West Indies.
Completed

But Friday and Sat. I had to go into the Shop again, as Mr. Cutler was most sick, Rheumatism in his back, bad. They were very hot, sultry days, and the Close confined air of the Shop after getting a full mouthful of the fresh open air of all out doors, haying, was almost enough to suffocate me made me fairly feel sick. I talked very strong of taking a regular Lobelia! but was cured not by steam but shower baths! I had a cold, and in my head, felt too full of blood. Pulling out one of the plugs in the floor, under the mill, afforded an excellent shower bath.

 I am retained to tale charge of the Shop all this week, as Mr. Cutler is going to Bangor tomorrow, and after that has got to go to Newport, and I shall have the finishing up of the Carding mostly, got about through with the carding this week, not week Mr. C. and Lysander will go preparing the fulling mill fixing up for the Cloth dressing business.
 Mr. Cutler says if I will I might stay, after this week, reaping then will be coming on, every body reaps grain here. I can find good chances to work out by the day reaping, if I wish to. I dont know, perhaps I shall come home in a week or so, to bring this letter to you, mei mamm. but I thought I would write a letter towards home to day as there has been meeting I could attend, and I felt rather homely.

There is a sort of Meeting up to Henry Hills corner, one of Millers lectures read by some one, but I concluded to stay at home. By the way the Miller doctrine is making quite an excitement about here. Many believe in it, perhaps most would think rather favorably of the subject, but some of the wild ones, (always some in every thing, you know) are so very about it. Even "young men see visions & old men dream, dreams" every thing, almost. lots of dreams, one man, Hall of Garland walked 9 miles with an angel, in a vision, many things revealed etc.
James', if the Judgment etc. is before the Millennium, what mean the thousand years after it is said that "Time shall be no more,"?

    Mrs. Upham & Joseph have today started for Mass. to go in the Boat tomorrow. It is really astonishing how that woman has acted, and the State of matters between her and Mr. Cutler's family. She has not been in to Mr. Cutler's or spoke to any one of the family, even her own Sister, since I have been here for months before and that too, living in the same yard, passing constantly by the open doors & windows, perhaps seeing every member of the family 20 times in a day. The family all take great pains not to trouble or intrude upon them either by presence or words in any way. It must make Mrs. Cutler feel disagreeably, - her face shows it when she turns away her head as Mrs. Upham passes the open window where she is sitting. 
 Mrs. U. has also taken me into favor in the same way. I believe, even been at the pains to circulate a few ? about me, although I have taken care not to offend her needlessly, at least, by sins of commission.
Completed

Tues. eve. Aug. 9th  I have just received Joseph's crowded letter, for which, 'all due thanks.'  I am - better this week. Did Charles work enough to pay his expenses? Did his work make him sick? why did not he tale a dose of Lobelia, or Hotdrops? what make yet behind with that leetle patch hoeing? Eliab why do not you look after those Michevous little foxes? So it appears that Joseph L.S. is fairly setting up for himself, is he 21 this summer or next?  Six month older or younger than I am? Is it a real "they say" about Mrs. Hamlin also? It struck me quite forcibly as a little queer: but on second thought perhaps it would be a very suitable match.

I guess I shall not go a fishing quite yet. perhaps  the Barkers will not go. David is much better. Mark Barker is going off to Sea, though, right off, to Europe, probably.

I guess I shall come home and get the Shirts,  perhaps before I send this letter.
You ask if I am going to be a Methodist. I believe I should have no objection to being called or being a Methodist, but I am not an Episcopalian. I admire & respect both the Methodists and their doctrines generally; it is true there are men, -?, unstable and imprudent, of more zeal than judgement  every where; and of course very many among the Methodists. but methodism, true Wesleyan Methodism- is extremely liberal, ready to yeild every thing and in every thing, except Christ and him crucified. That is the only tenet, which is the real 'sine qua non' of Methodism. It is not a quarrelsome or even sectarian sect; witness its relations with even the Church of England. I find no fault with either Methodist, Baptist, or Congregationalists on the score of doctrine. I have a faculty of harmonizing them all, as they are now held, by the most enlightened at least of each sect; but I dislike the constitution of form of Church government as it is called of one. and am very much opposed  to the Close communion of the Baptists, but even these distinctions are I hope, fast melting away. I see by the papers that a Cal. Bap. church in Amesbury, Mass. admits members with the privelege of communing with other Evangelical Churches.

   Lysander wants much to know whether there are any blueberries this year, and when they will be ripe. He has a good deal to say about the 'going a blueberrying'; was much pleased with his visit to Milo last summer, I guess.
I can not tell whether I shall come home this week or next or not till sometime later. I guess I will have a talk with Mr. Cutler tomorrow morning. I have pretty much the whole care of the Carding business, this week
Completed

I intend to be homesick or worse this winter, except evening. & no room to myself

[upside down] I want that trunk very much. Our writing master Sat. A.M. Tash, went to Brunswick one week vacation. Several Academy scholars from off. Treat, Enfield, Grant, Brewer, Butters, Exeter, 3 Lincoln. Those live here. going to me. Nancy Carpenter etc. and M. Edes Davis, Gocely etc. 

    As you said I must write, I spose I must. perhaps I shall have no better time than today as it is Thanksgiving and I do not keep School.  I have nearly 10 scholars already and more next week, no large ones yet hardly.

It is a case of a School, so many & about all of a size, a witching uneasy set of little rogues  as can be imagined. I never see such a task, it tries my patience much I hope to get them regulated,  a little in time. I hear 25 or 30 classes per day, mostly large, some near 20 in a class.

  I board at Mr. Parkers!  Circumstances prevented Mr. Stevens from boarding & Mr. Eldes had spoke to Mr. Parker, & I had . I have here no room to myself which is troublesome. chamber is cold & cant write or study there. 10 oclock is the family bedtime & I cant conveniently sit up longer which makes short evenings. Monday eve I went to Deacon Carpenter's , a very select party! Tash, Stevens, Fof? Holnes' girls. Eldridge Carpenter there. Seth, Susan, Abby, Nancy Nathan I like the family very well. I got back before 12, but found the door buttoned me out!

Mr. Parker's Thanksgiving sermon Abolition, "Remember those in bonds as bound with them" I dont know how liked.
The Tash has less 20 scholars.  Stevens is going to College Not much Thanksgiving here. Dinner at 12  & I got mine cold besides, no great loss though! Say their thanksgiving after Donation day. Next week thursday or 1 week after
I want my things in that trunk much some,.
[upside down] Sabbath 10th Quite a Snow - very - S.S. Drake of Garland preach today- World's Conversion - Millerism
Completed

Lucy. - Some Saturday, when pleasant & good Sleighing, you may expect Messrs Tash and Metcalf down to your place to see the folks and spend the Sabbath.  -- A word to the Wise etc. 
I intend sending this by J.L. Dennett - here. Have written some to mother--perhaps send it by and by or to you.
Isaac
Foxcroft  '42                                  Miss Lucy & A.M. Metcalf

                                                                Milo
                                Forward by J.L. Dennett
Completed

Brunswick, Oct. 27th, 1844

Dear Mother, Brothers & Sisters

                               Why dont you write to me? !!!

I have been very impatient to hear This long time from home, and got most tired of waiting. I wrote to Foxcroft, Case, one week after I wrote home, and received an answer today; which almost provoked me, or rather perhaps. That I did not from Milo.

I suppose however that you are all extremely busy, & in a 'desput' hurry, bother, turmoil, and fuss etc. etc. about the 'moving', and every thing else. I almost fear I am a little too selfish to want you to leave your active employments, & especially your never ending hurry to write to me, who am here like a bee in a hive, midst of the 'riches of the mind,' with nothing to do but to study and read; albeit College is not considered a very happy place.'except by those who have left it.' and the desire to hear from home, and to know how every thing progresses at the old place, amounts, almost to a mania in some cases, at times.

Although I have not heard from home yet, I could not forbear the temptation to write again, especially as Stevens intends to go home in a wee and I can send by him, at least as far as Foxcroft.   The Sabbath I believe is not generally considered by Students, as a very agreeable portion of time. They have to get up for prayers just the same, and are obliged to attend Church all day which is thought a real penance, and I am almost disposed to allow it. In the first place, the Students, are all obliged to sit together by classes in a gallery of the church, and the seats, are I believe without exception, the most uncomfortable I ever saw.
Completed

And the preaching is almost as bad. Parson Adams is an extremely dull, prosaic & monotonous speaker with a constantly similar concatenation of ideas, and a continual lullaby tone.
I dont know but I am too severe, but I really think they ought to have a better man in such a place, if for nothing else, even on account of the Students; it must be important to exercise a good influence on those who will so soon have so much influence themselves, either for good or evil  Students will appreciate good preaching as quick as any class, but none will sooner take disgust at poor.  I could but think as I looked round the gallery, to day, The Freshmen looked about as unhappy a set as could be, they have'nt got broken into it yet; the Sophomores & Juniors, mostly, part come in and compose themselves to sleep on the hard seats as comfortably as possible, and the rest open their book under their cloaks, and read as unconcerned as you please; while the Seniors, who have the best seats, and whose 'dignity' would be sullied by either of the other modes of killing time, 'grin & bear it', as by long experience taught.'

  Sabbath evening is by almost every one spent in getting the Monday morning's lessons, while I who always do that Sat., take the occasion, it seems, to write a letter home.

The State of Religion is very low indeed. There are but few comparatively professors of religion, and many of them no one would suppose to be. There is a Society called The 'Circle' which I expect an invitation to join soon, it meets for prayer etc. every Sab. Morn, every Sat. Eve, & every other Wed. but  the attendance is from 1/2 to dozen, & not more than 15 or 20 if one of the  Profs. lectures before Them.  The Circle has borne the imputation of being a Peucinian foil & many of the best in College, Athenaeians would not join. Of the last graduating class 3 or 4 now studying for the Ministry never attended it. Its President now however is an Athenaean.
Completed

By the way, the decision, to be made this term, which Society to join, is somewhat important, & quite perplexing. If not, as some pretend, it decides one's character for life, it certainly does, in a measure, one's companions and friends.  I suppose there is not, in reality, much if anything, to chose between them. The Peucinian is the oldest, and, perhaps, the most influential; the Athenaean the most active, and, perhaps, the most prosperous. The number of the College Societies differ not much; the members of the Athenaean have, it is said, taken the most prizes lately.

   The common amusement here is to do mischief, breaking windows is universal. You see all damage to College property is averaged and comes charged in every ones term bill, amounting usually to one or two $ per term apeice, for 150 or 200 students. One man is employed almost all the time in setting glass; the students call him a Prof. & say his professorship ought to be endowed. A, it costs, himself nothing, no one hesitates to throw an apple, an umbrella or a stove through a window, if it so please him. Sometimes the Freshmen windows are most all broken in a night. Kicking down doors is a favorite amusement with some. Every one would prefer to pay an average damage of $5. per term, rather than to inform. Canis Facultatis, or faculty dog, the name applied to informers, is the most opprobius epithet known. Some of the better part of the Students express their disapprobation of such state freely, but no one dares break through it. The first of this term, the dome & steeply of the College Chapel was sawed & thrown off one dark night. The faculty have made extraordinary efforts to discover the perpetrators! Every Student has been called up & cross questioned about it to no purpose., & it will probably be perhaps 100, in the average bill. I dont know how many knew who did it. Luckily I did not.

I wish you would send papers to me weekly, I cant get any to send, have none here. I mean to take one next term. Write to me all of you. frequently
Completed

Isaac
Oct. 27th / 44
Bowd.

                          Mrs. Anna M. Metcalf

Sabbath, Nov. 3 I was last night, initiated, it is called into the "Circle." The Candidates pass a formal examination of their religious experience & faith in the fundamental doctrines of the bible, before they are voted in. It is something like a church. 4 of the 8 who have entered Sophomores this term joined last night, only 2 of the whole Freshman class.  Had I better come home before finishing commencing School at Bangor? If I do I cant stay here more than 3 weeks longer. Will Charles be down about that time? I have had no washing done this term, & shall want to send some clothes home at any rate. I hope you will write as soon as next week, at any rate, or I may have started before receiving it.

I hardly know what to think about starting soon enough to go to Milo before my school. I dont care much about it. I shall want some washing done. though I have been rather saving & might get along a week or two. Write about it.
Completed

Bangor Dec. 30th, 44

Dear Folks

                   On coming home from my writing school tonight, I found a bundle for me having arrived during the evening, while I was about. It contained the old coat which is certainly very acceptable, though I have got on very tolerably without it, by forming the habit of going in school without any coat at all, which is very comfortable in a warm schoolroom. By considerable shaking & picking I found some pockets in the letters thereof, - not exactly - but, you know. I had got most through reading the letters before I began to suspect that Charles was the bearer of them; & when I did, I at first wondered that he did not stop at the schoolhouse & see me, but on second thoughts, I concluded that Ann was with him & they did not want to stop in the rain. They were rather unlucky in starting at such a time. 
   I was really gratified to think that I deserve such good letters from home,  & only hope I shall receive my deserts, if they are of such a kind. - I suppose it wont do to complain now however, if I dont receive them.
  The coat is very well, rather than I expected, and will do me good service, this winter. I dont know but I shall have to carry it back to Brunswick, which I had determined not to be worth the while. The handkerchief I needed. 
  The cloak I have not got, & dont intend to this winter,  I can get along with out it pretty comfortably. The thick boots I get on without very comfortably, especially since I have got the old on

[left-hand side] Excuse the writing, the girls laugh & talk so much & I am lazy as time
Completed

which answer a very good purpose, on snowy mornings, though they were mended in the most bungling manner possible I believe. a great junk of cowhide, I guess, boggled on over the old leather. The road here, you know, is always well trodden down constantly.

  If Joseph could only find a market for his rare talent of writing exordiums for letters, he might soon make his fortune. Unfortunately it does not seem a very useful science. I guess he will have a pleasant school enough: it is probably a good deal harder than mine though, "His class in Algebra - to wit- Albert book  & Lucy, wont compare with Mine of 8, 6 girls & two boys. Also Grammar, Who was Luther MKeems teacher? Pass the wood, to give him a kick. My blackboard is just big enough for four only. A. Cook, got beyond Arithmetic! I should admire to get him into my first Class in Colburn.  do him good. Arithmetic or Algebra cant be worth much without that. It is the beauty if these city schools; they have been trained in & to it, & believe in it. Every scholar who studies arithmetic is Colburn; and that first, Class, who are really good in Algebra, (Understood Smith's thoroughly before) all go into it and it is worth a while, I wish you knew.
 I should like to train a class of 40 country schoolmasters about one winter in Colburn's first lessons; it would be worth $1600,00 to the State next winter.
 Joseph's watch, I guess, sleeps cold. Wrap it up in a flannel rag & put it under your pillow.  What a boyish school! Mine about 3/4 girls.  I guess I must send you Smyth's Algebra---It will be good for your a/o quantities!
  Joseph can do those chores well enough if he dont have to chop the wood. I wish I had to do something. If I had not so very little time this evening, (twill soon be morning) I'd be glad to write J a separate letter!
Completed

I have commenced my writing School. Have less than 20 scholars. Only $.50 each, & I find all the Stationery.

I buy Writing Books, at $.50 per doz. at the Stores they are 6 1/4 each, I retail many at .5cts each, Penholders, 25 per doz. retail at, 4 each.
I bought a box of pens, 303, for $1,25.  They are 'Gillettes extra fine' 2 cents a peice, or, 25 the card of 12 & holder.  I sell lots, by the dozen, or a cent a peice. I bought a quart of ink for .37 1/2. I can supply you all with Stationery, of all kinds. I have also bought two half reams of letter paper, for $1.25 & .87 1/2, just half the quire price. Let me supply you all. The writing School, though it takes time will be no disadvantage to me, in reality, if I dont get much. I was at the 'City' Sat. night & Sunday. Next Friday night, if favorable, I mean to walk over to Levant, to Case's, and perhaps, spend the Sabbath. I.W. Case, teaches at Levant village & boards at home. He was down here Week ago one evening & went back the same night, with a good horse. Started back 11 3/4 P.m.
I usually sit up till midnight lately. I cant sleep all the time you know. I shall go to bed much earlier tonight, say 1 or 2 or 3

 I dont somehow make out study a great deal. I hope you will all take pains to write.

I hereby render many thanks to Joseph for his valuable letter. I hope I shall receive more like it frequently. I am about setting my scholars to Writing themes & Declaiming evenings etc.  This letter looks like a Writin Masters!!!  I believe I am doing well about Shirts linen etc.  I should like some linen wristbands artificial twice as long as others & I guess round cornered.
Completed

Bangor Jan. 12th, 1845

I was really gratified last Friday night, Jan. 8th, at receiving a very first rate letter, or rather letters, from Home. Aron Hill called at the schoolhouse; just before school was done and left them.

 By the way Aron looked as good natured & clever as you please, appeared glad to see me, and offered to carry up any thing I wanted to send up home. I intended then to write a letter to send up by him, but as it was an evening of the Writing School and more over my eyes were a little sore I did not make out to write.
   The letters did me more good than any thing this great while. Especially the History of "Joseph's doings with the Milo Sup. S. Com." which was enough to keep a man from hypocondria for a month even if much more disposed to it than I ever was.
 The result I think likely will do Joseph, & his scholars, some good, but perhaps Chadbourne & Macomber more.
  There is no trouble about Joseph getting along in any such condition, or in any situation where has to do only with his own sex.  He has got a pretty long head, and moreover his phrenological developements give him a great advantage over ever many others, and, especially, over me, in all matters of business.  But, the fact is, he is injuring himself far more than he has any idea of, by shunning, as he does, and always has, the society of the other sex.  His own reason would show him and in many ways, and he might see, even by a comparison of his own family, if he were acquainted with no others,  that females are, in many respects, really the better half of Creation.
Completed

three large X's across the entire page
I do not mean better in mind, nor do I say better in any respect naturally, 'though I do not know but there may be a natural, constitutional. difference in the sexes! 'but I believe better; purer, and having most of the finer, better feelings, of human nature; from circumstances, & education. Every external influence is with them, is not always at work to sink poor human nature still lower.  Many things contribute to make the character of females generally purer & better than that of males, so that if their Creator made them as good as the other sex, we may just conclude that circumstances have made them better.  Common Observation shows this, and also the excellent influence of female society, especially upon young men.  You may be sure to find the young man who is without any Sisters, destitute of the better part of human nature, at least if it has not been made up to him in some other way, while a really bad man, who had a good mother, and had been brought up in a family of good sisters, and other female society, would be an anomaly.  The beneficial influence of virtuous females, or the beneficial effect of their society has never been overrated.

 The extent of the ill influence of the unworthy part of the sex, proves nothing against the position; in fact it only strengthens it. for it illustrates the power & extent of female influence whether exerted for good or for bad.  I do not know as I have succeeded in any degree in conveying my ideas to the paper, but I do truly believe that the society, and intimate companionship of the really estimable of the other sex must, of necessity, have an effect to devote, to soften, and in truth to ennoble, the minds and characters of men, especially of young me, (minds easily acted upon), and in such degree & way as the society of the equally worthy of the other sex would not, if indeed any thing else could. Let then a young man who would form an agreable, useful, well balanced, happy, characters, select
Completed

X's across the page
indeed proper & good companions of the other sex, but by all means have them, as indispensable to a perfect character and a fair share of the better feelings of human nature, and let him become acquainted with then, intimate with them; Let him strive to benefit them, and he can, for they have human minds, immortal ? minds, as well as his own, and perhaps less cultivated, but as capable of cultivation; and he may be sure that his own mind & his own heart will receive at least reciprocal benefit.

  I think our whole systems of education & life are erroneous in the arbitrary distance which they strive to maintain between the sexes; its effect is certainly bad upon one of the sexes, probably both.
 The absurd & ridiculous idea or ideas of the so called passion of love, ideas first perhaps brought it into being by the Old romance of Chivalry, and perpetuated in a measure by our modern words etc.; and upheld apparently with strange tenacity by all our systems of life, and the form & ceremonies which regulate all the intercourse of the sexes, are to be reprobated perhaps. 
            I guess it is lucky that P happened to think of going to bed the other night, or I do not know what would have become of this letter, or what would have been the end of the rigmarole. I can just remember that I began to write a sentence led on to another, not thinking that it was to be succeeded by still another, till the Essay or the yarn was spun out to such a lenght & shape. Looking at it again, I scribbled it & would have thrown away, but on reflection, I have concluded to send it, for I really believe it contains some truths of a genus which might benefit Joseph; if they were of the right species, and he could only bring his
Completed

mental eyes to bear upon them, and would follow the dictates of his own decisions.

 I believe it is absolutely necessary for the benefit of his character that he should mix in the society of the other Sex, more than he has yet done.

Jan. 12, 1845

 - Isaac  -                                                              Metcalf
Completed

Bangor, Jan. 19th, 1845
  My school is now just finished; and so is the celebrated writing school. I am really pleasantly situated here, and have a very pleasant school as well as in writing school.  The writing school is really a good one in spite of Joseph's insinuations: it is small to be sure, and the terms still smaller, but the scholars are really good ones, and many of them quite good writers; as for the improvement they make, I only wish you could see their books.
   There are eighteen in all, but one or two of them, for not all the time. They have all paid me but three of them, & they will next evening.  The Stationery for the School would amount to about $3.00; though I bought about, $6.50 worth in all including the two half reams of paper. I bought a gross of pens,  you know for $1.25, I have sold more about .50 of them besides .25 I sent home. I have also sold one doz. writing books, at the enormous profit of one cent each, being at that as much cheaper than the stores usual price.
 I bought one 1/2 ream of paper for $1.25 and one for .90, and sold one fourth of each to Green who boards here for $.75. Ann bought 12 sheets like the best, at Duren's since she came down and gave .15 for it,, 30 per quire. $6.00 per ream.
   About a fortnight ago, I started Friday night, Jan 3d and walked up to Levant; about 7 miles, after school, and staid both Sat. and Sunday at Dr. Case's. They appear to be very fine sort of people. Isaac W. Case is teaching the school at Levant village, and boards at home. I went to
Completed

his school, Saturday forenoon. He has a pretty good school, but not near as pleasant as mine, larger 60 or 70 scholars, but not so forward, though more so, & pleasanter every way than mine was last winter at Foxcroft. His school closes at the same time with mine, and he will go right on to Brunswick.

 By the way, I shall want much to go up to Milo again before starting for College, as I dont know when I shall come back, but you see, it will be two or three weeks into the College term, and the classes going right ahead into the every thing, and every thing else doing - the Spring term is the worst of all to be absent, and every day will be worth a great deal too much to lose, if it can be avoided; so I shall not want to take time to go home after my school is done ~ and  ~ as the sequel to this prelude, I have the idea in my noddle to start some Thursday night or Friday and go up to Milo & stay till Sunday night or Mon. morn.
 Saturday Morning. I spread out my umbrella and got behind it, and it carried me down to the City through the snow, just as easy as you please. I found Ann well, but Mr. Pomroy has got the Bronchitis, (a very fashionable disease, you know, means that a great man has a sore throat.)  so that he dont preach, or go out doors, or even into a room with a fire in it without consulting its thermometer.  Grandmother, Old & Mrs. Harlow, is also quite unwell, has been very sick, but they think is a little better.
 She looks very miserably & is very weak & I do not believe she can live long.  I was intending to stay over the Sabbath, but as the folks were sick etc. I concluded to come back.

Ann has so much to do that she cant even find time to write it seems; she promised to have a letter written by Sat. but had'nt time & could not find time then. She was pleased with the
Completed

letters I carried to her, & wanted I should write to Lucy to write good long letters to her also. She had nothing to write without she had time to tell a real long story etc. etc.
The fact is ~ She, & the rest of the folks, do not like to write letters like Lucy & I. If she did, I presume, she thinks enough about a great embroidered, painted, crewelised, bed quilt that they showed me there once, to write a doz. letters on't.

 Now I happen to think of it, I have got no clean shirt to wear this week. There are collars & bosoms enough- and to spare, but no shirts. I expected you would have sent some by A. P. Hill or somebody. I had only two besides one on my back when Charles was down here. It would be no kind of trouble however to wear some of them over two or three times more, except that I have formed the habit of going without my coat in the school room, to save such furniture. A white shirt is apt to get dirty in a week or two, in a dirty school room, and it would be a pity of the girls should think it necessary to give me to a shirt!
  How would it work to affix, by sewing process, a lot of those old narrow bosoms, That are not really, hardly fit to wear any other way, upon some of the shirts. I should like some such very well if they could be made to get decently any how. They could be worn 1/2 week & then another over them.
  By the way have I got shirt enough to last me a year if I want? And is there any good coarse cloth there to make more? Does Lucy walk to school? Does Charles finish off the house? Does that 'four ox team' in the barn find any thing else to do. besides eat up the hay? and have a a man to tend Them? I should think it an uphill business for the owner? No hay to sell?
Completed

Susannah has had a headache this week, and is now about sick, and can not go to school, and I am sorry about it.

  My College bond ought to have been attended to when I was at home. I forgot it. It must be send up home & filled up out, and sent back again. I cant go back to College without it you know. Has not my College Term bill arrived at Milo. It was due in December. I want to see it. Find my expenses, & how I got on there rank etc.

Isaac Jan. 17

Bangor Jan. 26th, 1845

Specimen of an Exodium {I believe I must take the liberty, or rather the opportunity, to write another letter today, as it is Sabbath & stormy, and I happen to be here at home again and not much to do; although I have written some, before, I guess, but it has become a little musty by this time I guess; although there has nothing of interest taken place since, and nothing to mark a mark on the time so we could remember it, except that one Sabbath follows after another}

 I ought to have sent up home last week, but Cutts, I did not see, and it as so stormy there was no body else on the road, I believe, from so far up country. 
  The storm & blow, Tuesday & Wednesday, filled up the roads finely, and do dry that it did hardly got trod down so as to make good roads or good walking before the great rain storm.
  I need some clean shirts much, I hardly see how I happened to be so destitute. there are plenty of linen here but only three shirts. one of them has already been worn two weeks & the another is now undergoing the same. 
             It troubles me to think of that $5,00 I owe to Caleb Prentiss, and which was to be paid in three months, which would be in December. I hoped to have enough from my writing school to send it up to him, but have not after paying what I run in debt for Stationery etc. and if I had I want it bad enough for other purposes; however I live upon anticipation in that as in every thing else: five weeks more and I shall have some money: but it also troubles me to think how extremely
Completed

will be that supply, when compared with my necessities, you see I shall get $50.00, or $60, dollars from my school, and I ought certainly to carry as much as that to Brunswick with me, to pay all my bills and start me there, without thinking anything of the next term, or indeed of any thing else; and then I truly need about as much as that to clothe me decently. It is astonishing how destitute I am, I believe I never was quite so much before. I have no clothes fit to wear into the school room hardly, much more to go into the city, to meeting, or any ?. I dont hardly know how I do get along. I believe I never was disposed to think much of the future or of the past, if the present only slipped along easily; and lately it seems that I am strangely indifferent to the present also, that is as far as regards all external circumstances.  In fact I believe I live too much in myself and am affected by other things of any sort.

   Wed. Eve After Writing School

I was very much gratified tonight on coming home from school to find a bundle from home, left by Mr. Coutts; as it happened I needed it considerable, in the matter of shirts.

 By the way, I dont believe I have got shirts enough, if I should stay at Brunswick till next winter, & you know it would not be very easy to send; and, if there is any cloth at home suitable it would be a good plan to have some made, I wish some of those old narrow bosoms of which there are so many could be fastened on to some shirts if they could, there would be plenty of bosoms & collars, I guess; and I dont know about stockings.
Completed

I send up that College bond which it is necessary should be filled out & back before I go back.

I have got a first rate 'second class' of some 8 or 10 or 12 pretty little girls, all about of a size, 7 or 12 years old to whom I promised to give a present. They are all first rate scholars & I guess it will be as much as puzzle to tell to which it belongs.

 However I wish you would send me down something as would do for presents. There is a little book, Blake's Geography, used to belong to me would be good if it is around the house.
 Tell Eliab that a "School Master" ought to have more eyes in his head than to be run over by any bodies team. What do those little rogues do behind him? or does he turn round so often that no one is ever fairly behind him?
 As to Smith's men, will Almeda get her pay? I suppose Smith pays his debts when he is obliged to, but he has the repute of being a hard customer. I suppose she does not their washing. Washing is not part of a laboring man's board, usually.
  Is not Eliab's school most done? This is the eight week of mine, 2/3 done. How long, is Joseph's, & what wages does he have? I will send J. some paper when I can without touching it till then let him use the other.
 Take care of your taters, they will be high, Any body could get rich here by raising them alone. Milo is too far from City, for one live except by increasing property.  People can live easier here.
 Dont be alarmed at my setting up late, I go to bed in good season & sleep a great plenty. I have lost 2 or 3 hours in twenty four all winter in sleep but still I might more appropriately send to you on that subject. Mt eyes have been a little sore but  are better - well. I hurt them probably, going up to Levant
Completed

Sat & Sun. bright sunshine on new snow & I had not been out much before. I wish you would send me several things that little last years almanac of mine, my phren. chart, & if Lucy pleases, those old Bowd. Cats. they are of no use at home, you only want the late ones as I send to you and they will be good for me.
Isaac
Janu'y 26 / 45                                     Metcalf
Bangor

Framingham                                                                         Brunswick March 9th, 45

 I am here at Brunswick, arrived Friday night at 11 P.M. (and the way I have had the 'Blues' since I have been here is by no means slow, considering that it is me, who am not often troubled with such sort of critters, you know.  However, let me tell you the whole history since I left Home.  When I started I waited awhile for Severance  and then went on. down to Bradford & there waited. Severance got along there at most 3 oclock, and stopped to bait?, Said he should go down to Merritt that night, and in early in the morning.  I got a chance to ride down to Merritt ( and went on Got to M Dudley's in the eve. The next morning I waited & waited till I was tired, for Severance to come so I might get my trunks ready etc. At noon Walked in to the City, and streets in snow & mud the rest of the time. Bought a Cloak, pair pants, & Vest,  of Oliver Dresser & Co. for $16.00. The vest was 1,25, or 1,00. The Pants 4,50 or 4,00. The cloak was perhaps a little better than those I found at other places for 13,00 to 15,00, the same sold last fall for 16,00 to 18,00.  You see it is not the season for Cloaks to sell, & every one was anxious to sell. This one had been worn a few times, but just as good, price $15.00

I have repented that I bought so valuable one, for I could not at all afford it any how. though it seemed somehow necessary to my 'doing.'
I expected Severance all that day with the greatest impatience. He might at least have sent the trunk along by Cutts.   Severance arrived the day after, Thursday, March 6th, at 10 1/2 oclock. So I could not leave Bangor till Friday.  The Stage starts at 4 A.M., but the rascally waiter waked me up before 3 instead, so I slept only three hours.

The travelling was very bad. Stage went on wheels all the way, but some of the way, over the Diamont hills etc. the snow was drifted much much of the way, Muddy, terrible rough & icy besides some times
Completed

The stage was $3.00 to Augusta 10 miles, and $2,00 from there to Brunswick. 30 miles which is 50 more than I expected, and outrageously too high.

 I rode all the way to Augusta in a single wagon. The regular Coach was more than full, and so they took a wagon beside. They had good smart horses, and changed them every 10 or 12 miles like the Stage, it was more pleasant than inside the Stage, but perhaps more tiresome, as the wagon was not a very east one, and most of the at three in it, & fast riding.
I did not have time at Augusta, even to see the State house, hardly any thing else. The travelling was so bad that we did not get to Bruns. till 11 + oclock, instead od 9, so had to stay at tavern. Stage fare 5,00, Foods, lodgings etc. about $1,00 more. So you see I arrived here less than $40,00.!

of which I was owing my Chum, you know, about 5,00. My board in the Club I have paid $6,00. Furniture things bought last fall & Postage and so forth I have paid 2 or 3 dolls.  So you cant tell how poor I am. I have not seen my term bill yet, it will probably be about $24, or 25,00 besides the years tuition $24,00, which I suppose I shall be obliged to pay whether or no. However, for some consolation hereafter, it has been afixed to me to take charge of one of the Recitation Rooms which will for a remuneration $10.00, though I have to pay one of my Classmates for taking it till I arrived. As the furnace is now broken it is just to keep fire in one room. Coal is used though, which is dirty. Have to build the fire about 5 oclock I suppose.

 The worst of it all is that I arrived here Friday night at 11 oclock on the same night of the Society Initiations, just a day behind the fair. which am a real Scrape. I would have given $5,00 & a good deal would not pay the loss. for it seems I cant join, & lose all the benefit of the Societies full the next term.
Completed

I have got my 'term bill.' It says $50,00 or 48,96 !! I dont know as there is any way I can get rid of paying the last year's bills. I shall try hard though.
Tuition 8,00                                                           Believe I shall till the Prix, that I cant pay it, should be obliged to go right off & earn the money and
Rent   3,43                                                           perhaps wont come back. Much as I could do to come at all & not to blame for not coming sooner.
Av.dam.?1,79 Much more than usual, too bad.
Inceping?1,00, Woman who makes beds etc.
Library ,50 Whether one reads or not.
Monitor ,11 Monitor receives 13 dolls. per term
Bell       ,14 Bell ringer received 16,66 per term.
Rec.rooms,85 For care of recitation rooms, fuel & lights, lights never used.
Wood   1,06 Wood is $4,25 per cord, it is a college Monopoly.
Books   3,45 I had to buy some books last fall of the College, as you know my money was scarce
Board  1,72 I boarded a little in the Commons before going to the club.
Chem.lec. 1,00 I suppose I am charged for lectures four terms, all last year
Com. dinner 2,00 Also commencement dinner & order of Exercises, which seems to be charged to every Student, 50 per term,  although coming only once a year, & then no student permitted to be present at the dinner till after he has graduated!!! 
The Chemical lectures are only one term in a year, and then no one is permitted to attend them till his Junior year.
Ad.standing 24,00  I have paid $20,00 on my term bill & have got perhaps 7, left. If I can make them take off the last year charges, say 26,25, perhapa I can get along. The next term bill ought not to be but about $15,00. I shall get some 7,00 for building fires, and mean to some for sawing wood. I felt rather blue when I first got here, & heartily wished my self back again, especially being after initiations. & so little money, but I begin to feel a good deal better and am very fast making up my lost studies, 15th was examined on the fall's studies & passed fairly. 3 weeks of this term to study for yet though. 
I board in Club as fall, cost then, 948 per week. Chum & I little idea hurting ourselves.
I suppose you got the trunk I left at Bangor with its contents. You know my umbrella. AD end of handle. I left it in the bar room at the Bangor House!
Completed

you do not begin to guess how I want to hear from home, and all how you are all getting along, Joseph & Eliab, I suppose are about finishing their schools, and I want to hear much all how they got through, whether they got their money, how much, & what they are going about now, & for the season. Lucy's school, I suppose continues much yet! (Dont work too hard) 'Take you time, Miss Lucy! In school & out. By the way, Lucy sit down in school and write me a real good long letter some day. I dont believe in too hard too much work for too little. I have done too much of it myself already. At any rate 'do write' all of you, Mother do write Joseph & Eliab Ann, I want to hear about all your affairs. & Charles business etc. etc.
I am sorry I did not carry you some great foolscap paper to write me letters on this Spring. Write Soon.
Elizabeth Bangor Bangor Bangor Bangor Bangor
