Northfield, Nov. 6th, 1847.

Last night I had the greatest feast for a long time. I received a large double letter from Milo, and another similar one from Bangor. I had been anxiously expecting letters for some time. There were more than twelve full pages in the two letters.
You say, Dear Mother, that you do not have so much to write about as one away from home so far. If you only thought how interesting any thing and any thing coming from home, when one is so far away, you would fine there is enough to write about. And if you knew how beloved your letters always are, you would never think it not worth while to write them.
You want to know what kind of a man my present superior Mr. Field is. Alfred R. Field Esq. is one of the Northfield Fields. I believe I have already written something about him. He is thought considerable of about here. Cousin Joseph especially likes him much. But I do not like him very well. I suppose he considers himself a Unitarian, but he is rather one of the Ultra, Radical sort. a great admirer & follower of Theodore Parker. and R.W. Emerson. A Radical Temperance & Abolition man. as well as in religious matters. I call him almost an Infidel. though. He is a nervous sort of a little fellow, and when vexed he will swear just a little, below his breath. He has had much experience as a surveyor. I do not think very highly of him as an Engineer. his is a little short sighted, quite a failing for an Engineer. He has however always used me very well.
Completed

You ask how I like the Northfield Unitarian Minister, Mr. Everett. He is quite a young man, son of a rich Boston Capitalist, & rail road Stockholder, Educated at Harvard, established here by his Father, a very honest, well intentioned sort of a man, but without talent, and uninteresting as a preacher. The Unitarians  here can never do much, there is so much done for them.  Old Pomroy, I believe his name was, a rich old rascal long ago, built a fine Church, and set apart a sufficient fund to support abundantly a clergyman to preach Harvard Theology. People have nothing to do but go and hear him preach, and keep up old Pomroy's restrictions. The Orthodox Clergyman., Mr. Jones has been to Persia as a Missionary. did not succeed they say. Why I know not. For my part I like him. He is a very good preacher.
Aunt Esther has gone to Barnard Vt. to spend the Winter with Samuel Conant. I wanted to see her again. I have hardly seen her but a few minutes. I walked out from Northfield to Uncle Williams once, principally to see her, but she had gone to take care of the sick somewhere and I did not see her. Aunt Conant, I only saw one day, I was up there when I first came hereabouts. Cousin Maria is at home, only she is here at Northfield this week. By the way I ought to call there again to see her before she goes home. But since I returned from Putney, Thurs night, I have been confined every moment almost in the day & evening in the R.R. Office. I am writing this only while waiting for Field to come in: as I have got out of business, till I can see some of  his notes. Yesterday & today I have been doing office work, making calculations, plotting lines, drawing plans, profiles etc. I do not know but I shall do so well they will [right-hand side] want me to stay in Acc. Office most all winter.
[left-hand side] Isaac Nov. 6th 1847
Completed

of land like that is enough to make a man wealthy in dozen years. Why! people do succeed farming on plains, such sandy land as is in Milo. The difference is this. Both cultivate easily. One holds Manure six months. the other 60 or 600.

                                                                                                R.R. Office, Northfield Nov. 22nd. 1847

It is about a fortnight since I wrote last to folks at home, but I suppose, though I visit the Post Office regularly daily, that it is entirely superfluous to expect letters from home for a fortnight to come, perhaps for a whole month.  Yet somehow I cannot help writing. Even if I think, from your not writing, that you do not wish to hear from me, I want to hear so much that I cannot refrain from writing.  Thursday will be Thanksgiving Day, in Maine, and in the "old Commonwealth" the same. How I should like to be with you! Will the Bangor Brethren & Sister be up to the Home?
I suppose likely I shall go out to Warwick. The cousins here all go out, both families, old & young. They are very kind, always ready to carry me out etc. Some of them go out most every Saturday to spend the Sabbath.
I went out with Joseph & Jane a fortnight since. Humphrey is to be up from Boston this week. They are determined I shall go. I had about as lief stay here, have the day to myself, hear a really splendid sermon, which our Parson Jones is going to preach. I do very much like the man's preaching; plain, practical, common sense; very little imagination, or eloquence, straight forward ideas, argument thoughts; and talked right off, not read. After all preaching a sermon is better than reading one like Wm. S. Sewall, Geo E Adams, and most others. Let a man study his subject & sermon just as much, or rather a little more, have it at his command: notes perhaps but not confined to them, their loss not stop him); and then have the faculty, and train it, and perfect it, of putting forth his ideas in words, as he needs them. This to me seems to be all but, if not quite essential to the successful Orthodox Minister at this day. It does very well for the Unitarian to read off his smooth Moral
Completed

Essay: perhaps indeed it sounds best so, unless in some extreme case of a man of some splendid rhetorical powers, a natural orator. But a sermon ought not, to take effort, to be read. Whatsoever others may do, New Englanders will not now as their fathers did, or as perhaps Scotchmen will now, sit an hour or two hours to hear a man read an dry (musty I almost said), theological argument. They may sit the Modern half hour; even for that short time, really hear! not one in ten, as far as any observation or experience goes. To interest people, to make them hear you, you must talk to them, reason with them, speak to them, not read at them, or as many do merely read in the house where they sit.  It was my utter, absolute incapability of doing this, of talking, speaking to people that convinced me that I ought not, could not, be a Minister. Even if my heart & my head were full- my tongue would be lacking. I should have nothing to say, that is, no words to say it in. I feel this to be my exceeding great infirmity, and I believe it grows upon me. Perhaps my circumstances are not very favorable to the cultivation of whatever slight faculty of speech I may possibly possess. At College, among so many having the same thoughts & feelings, bound & affected by the same circumstances and influences, within & without, I could of course contrive to express the common stock of ideas, or let others express them for me, so as to get along after some decent fashion.  In the circles of domestic life, among old tried intimate, perfectly acquainted friends, I think likely it might be the same. but among strangers, or more casual acquaintances, all whose thought, feelings, sentiments, ideas & sensations even, are different from my own, I find it almost impossible to speak even as much as the forms of society require, even to answer civil questions decently.
I declare what an essay I have been writing here. Lets see, what was I writing about? O Thanksgiving! I would have procured a team & gone over to Royalston that day, if I could have managed to procure an invitation.
Completed

I really want to go over there but I do not know when I shall. This business confines one very much. It is next to impossible to get away for a day or an hour. Possibly one may have nothing to do just now, but he must be all ready for it if it comes next minute, next hour or next week. As for myself, they seem inclined to make a Draftsman of me. You see Engineers all going off from here on the Mountain Survey, hardly any one was left who could do any thing. They found out I could use a scale & dividers, and in fact I have been in the Office most all the time since we came from Putney. Should not be surprised from present appearances, if I were kept here in the Office now all the time this Winter.  On some accounts, perhaps it will be better for me. I shall get to be quite a Topographical Draftsman. It may be less wearing than constant Exposure to all weathers, though more constant. day & evening. I find I shall feel the cold more when I am out. If I had kept right on out all the time I believe I should have felt the need of no additional clothing, over coat, under shirts, even a vest, all winter. Of I stay in a Warm Office most of the time, I shall need to dress warmer when I am out on line.

 Sat. eve. Well. There was a tremendous rain here on Wednesday: it troubled people who wished to go home to Thanksgiving. I went out to Warwick on the Stage Thursday Morning. Mr. Parsons & wife & children went out in the storm, Wednesday! Humphrey S. arrived at 4 1/2 P.M. Wed. from Boston. I went up to Aunt Conant's and spent the forenoon. All Well. Lately heard from Aunt Esther at Barnard, likes well there much pleased all well etc. With great effort & much ingenuity, I escaped from Uncle Ben's in time to meet a positive Engagement at Thanksgiving dinner at Capt. Joe's. Returned to Northfield Friday Morning. Found my Boarding Place upside down & wrong side out from Effects of the great R.R. Ball there held.
Completed

I should like to convince Charles of what I have often thought & perhaps told him, that he does most abominably undervalue & considerably misuse his intervale lands. It seems to me I could convince him, if I had him here, that one acre of than Intervale rightly used was worth more than any other five acres he has; perhaps as Milo taxes are than the whole the rest. I should like to show him these intervale lands along the Connecticut River; have him examine the lands, their prices, their crops. If these lands are now valued at from one to two hundred dollars per acre: sell quick at that. This you will remember too is - until the Rail Roads are built - farther from Market that you are at Milo. - And most richly are they worth those prices, when compared with the upland farms, at any price. Suppose two farms, producing with good cultivation the same. It makes a great difference with the profits, and with the real value of the farms, whether the cost of cultivation is 99/100 & more, or 9/100 the value of the crop. But you will say that these Conn. River intervales are much richer naturally than yours. I do not believe it. I dare you to prove it - by testing yours with equal cultivation.
One thing for the Intervales here. Hoof of grazing beast, horse, cattle, sheep or hog, never touches them. They will produce prime crops without Stable Manure indeed. Why the Full growth of Grass left on them every year is worth more than any manuring you ever gave your land two years in succession. But they do manure these lands. The secret is not that they need no Manure but that every ounce of Manure instead of washing away as it does from every upland acre into every brook & valley, stays there.
Your intervale may be by mismangement run out but if I wanted to make farming profitable, it would be by a dozen acres of that, rather than by any upland farm in Milo. And Public opinion, not in Milo, but throughout the valley of the Conn. would sustain my estimate. People here whom Uncle Jos. tells of your intervale farm suppose of course you are wealthy, and a peice
[right-hand side] Isaac Nov. 22 - 47
Completed

I M M Mr   L.H. 1847

Brattleboro is quite a village, and appears to be a very thriving business place. On the other side of the Connecticut river, which river belongs entirely to New Hampshire, rises abruptly a high hill, this overtopping almost overhanging the Village so that the Sun usually rises at Brattleboro ' a little while before it sets at Capt. Jos. Stevens' in Warwick. Brattleboro is now the Terminus of quite a number of Stage routes, into several different States; and already the Centre of a good deal of business: which moreover will increase greatly when our Railroads are built, especially if the travel of the great West, or even a portion of it comes this way. By the way, our Engineering, (and who are better judges, or have better opportunities of judging?) think that about  the greatest chance for speculation, now in the Country, is at a place they call "Grouts" Grouts Tavern I suppose: which I believe is on or near the Conn. River, at or near the mouth of "Miller's River." It has, I believe, abundant Water priveleges, and other advantages "too numerous to mention." It will be on the proposed route just equidistant from Boston & Troy; the great half way house, Stopping to Dine place etc. besides a junction place of branches. The place has hardly begun to exist in imagination even, yet: and those
Completed

who invest there first may realize hundred or thousand fold.
I do not yet know how well to like Brattleboro', not being in the slightest degree acquainted with a single resident. It certainly contains many fine looking private residences, environed with shrubbery. The State Insane Hospital is I believe, considered the principal thing. The Water power used, in the Manufacturing is not the Conn. River, though I should think it might be but two or three brooks here emptying into the Conn.

On the West side of the Conn. River both in Mass. & Vt. I should judge that the land rose very gradually swell after swell, or broken ridge after ridge, away back towards the Green Mts. On the East side, it is certainly abrupt enough down at Mt. Holyoke; at Northfield there is a level plain, one, two, or three miles wide, on the river, back of which rise rough steep hills. Above, in N.H. the hills some clear to the river most all the way from Kinsdale up by Chesterfield etc.
    It appears that all of our Warwick relatives, except indeed Aunt Esther, are Unitarians. All Uncle Joseph's folks are very stout ones, I judge. Especially Cousin Hannah. I had to exercise all my skill to avoid an "argufying the topic"  with her. She is about as "tonguey" a woman as I know. Her husband, Albert E. Parsons, I like very much. Joseph A.S.'s wife is a remarkably amiable character. Her name was Jane Wells of Shelburne Mass
Completed

I love Aunt Conant, she is so much like our Mother. She is too a very superior woman naturally; but shut up all her life, as if in a quart pot; confined to one little narrow spot & round of duties, thus and so performed; no opportunity to grow, although large hearted and large minded by nature.

 Uncle Joseph is an extremely perfect character; that is well balanced. He is like a Carrot, grown, say in a tin tube, just exactly filled it out, not very large, but perfectly round and true. Who shall say how much the growing up on that little narrow, rocky, ancestral homestead, "those few paternal acres," under the trees his father planted, and among the rock where his fathers lived & labored & died. have had to do in the forming such a character as is his. There must indeed have been strength & vigor & greatness even from the original stock; but the steady integrity, the honest sound judgment which have made him honored and respected among men, the trusted Referee, the just Arbitrator, and the popular Commissioner, whence came they else?

But Uncle Jacob I do love. There does'nt seem to be any self about the man I want to get more acquainted with him.
Completed

Brother Joseph, this Chest is not much a letter any way. Another is headed "Dear Mother". Perhaps the whole may be superscribed "J.M. Metcalf." You will please read (that is if such trouble be consonant with your wishes, feelings, interests, and time), and offer the same to Eliab and Anne for reading, and then, if you please, see that it reaches Milo, as soon as possible. It is a long time since I have heard from you. I am anxious thus to do, and that frequently, particularly, upon any or all subjects, business (which I am much interested in), literature, science, politics, anything, thoughts etc. let the correspondence be frequent prompt

   Brother Eliab, the same write I also unto you. It is certainly worth the while for both of us, that we keep up a regular, frequent, full correspondence. Nothing shall be wanting to it on my part. We can both find time. We may be hurried, have a great deal to do, and scant time and facilities to do it.  I may have to write her a log, by a camp fire, at midnight. But it is best to write. You know, - No,  If you did you would write more.you do not know how much I want to hear & know if all your doings, feelings, pleasures & interests, your advantages & your improvements.

Now do write.
Sister Anne, For one who can be so good, so valuable a correspondent as you can, I hardly think you always do all your duty in writing to your absent brothers.
Now I want you to consider how much good effect in a Sister's letters may have upon a young man so far away from home and in great measure from most all the good influences of home, friends, and most every thing else. except those contained in letters; and Write accordingly.
All news & every thing else will of course be interesting to me. Please offer my best respects to Miss Doe etc. And Answer any inquiries of Mr. Harlow or any of his family the best you can
[right-hand side] Isaac
Completed

1848

Dear Sister Almeda, Why do you not write to me? Do you not like to hear from me, or from any absent brothers' & sisters', or friends? Do you not think then that I must the same? How long do I be away and never hear a word from you or from Children, except a word or two casually in letters of Lucy perhaps. Do not begin to say that I do not write to you; because my letters are not directed to you personally. I write letter home, that is to the folks at home of course all usually read them. They contain all I have to say, or write about. It is therefore just the same as a letter of the size, to every one who reads it, separately, if they were separate You ought to do your part of the writing. I want to hear how all your affairs are getting along. how the Children prosper etc. Do the Children go to school this winter? Who does your Chores etc.
Charles. I wish I had your oxen here; that is if you want to sell them. Or your horse either. Teams, of all kinds are extremely hight about here, occasioned partly perhaps by the demand for labor along the Rail roads. Any decent yoke of oxen will bring one hundred dollars, or a decent horse.  This Railroad building every one to work that will work; increases the demand and consequently the price for every thing. All sorts of lumber, and even wood, is almost doubled in price.
I believe I wrote you a long story a while ago about your Intervale lands. I want to tell you something else whereby perhaps a comparison of your experience with that o those who know the management of such lands for a century may be beneficial. They say here, never plow intervale land in the Fall it is not land ever flowed either. If you ask the Old Men or any
Completed

of the river farmers when to plow; they will say not over four days before you put in the crop; another will say two pleasant days is full enough. Even turning in a crop, sometimes done, is never in the fall, I believe. It is very usual to sow Clover. Mow once. (the Meadows are usually mowed twice) Let the After crop lay on the Ground, till Spring, then plow it in, and sow, or plant immediately.
Mother. I do not know about this plan of your excusing yourself from Writing (because Lucy writes. If she does well, and writes good letters, it is no reason why you should not also. I want you should both of you write.  Let me see have I told you of Mr. Jones' Donation Party. The last Thursday of December. It was the Only evening I have been out of the Office since we got back here from our Putney excursion 1st of Nov! Just as likely as not there are some people about here who would like to pull me into Society here. Well, I had previously made up my mind to attend that Donation. But the Evening before a young Gent, one of the Managers or getters up of the affair, took a good deal of pains to introduce himself to me & give me a Special invite. He took much pains to introduce me to some of the young folks.
I have of course got acquainted hereabouts principally only with those with whom business brings one in contact. the Old Men. Capitalists, business men etc. I got finally pulled in at Parson Jones' though. An old box was passed round to receive what money contributions might be made. Thinking it a fair opportunity to do I might for support of Gospel. A Salaried Young man is expected to have money you know. I threw in a bill, only a one. Come to fid out, the box had been passed round to all the rich men of the town, and there are such, and had nothing in it bigger than a quarter!
Completed

Seems to me, I want to fill of this page, although I hardly think of any thing to write. One thing perhaps I better tell you now of what I have been thinking that if I go down East in the Spring My Mother will probably have to come back to Massachusetts with me. By the way how would it work for my absence one week next Spring to lose me my situation on Vt. & Mass.? It is a very rare thing for an Engineer to have leave of Absence. Even if there is nothing at all for him to do; he knows nothing how soon there will be, and must remain at his post. My Wages are Since Nov. 1st $40 per month . Next Spring they ought to be $50.00 or 60.00 I now do the work of $2.00 per diem Wages; but "the experience"etc.   You know ~

 By & by after there Comes Settled Cold Weather & deep Snows probably so as to Create Out door Work bad. they will be ready to send me off up into Vermont, to level over the Bellows' Falls line. What do they do about the mail box? Block up all the roads & stick up red flags, before the houses?  Who is Nathanial Stevens of Warwick. A rusty looking old lumber dealer, reputed a Slacker, hard case etc. Who is always so glad to see me, and makes such awkward mistakes in enquiring after the family, My Uncle Charles, Mother's three oldest daughters etc. When I needed it not I copied off once a sheet of Genealogical affairs. When getting into circumstances to need it I was thoughtful enough to leave it at home. Why, if I had bring it here, when infinite sum of vexation of spirit to say nothing of confusion of face, it would have saved me about acknowledging my relation. Really, I doubt if I know now the names of one in ten of my cousins, done the best I could to find out too, darsn't betray my ignorance by direct inquiry you know!

I.S.M. Goffstown
March 25. 1849

                                                                                                                              Sabbath March 25th 1849

Dear Mother & Sister Lucy and other folks at Milo
You can see by the date above when I write, Where perhaps I cannot quite as well explain. I believe it is in the South West corner of Goffstown or perhaps "West Goffstown". New Hampshire. If not within the limits of West Goffstown, it must be in "West Boston", or in "East Ware." The place is called "Parkers," and it is very near a Post Office called "Oil Mill Village". Perhaps it is enough that it is on or near the line of the New  "New Hampshire Central Rail Road," so called; whereof I begin to suspect that I am, or am like to be an Engineer.
There, that will do for a preamble!
Well. Yesterday was Saturday, but I did not get home last night, not even to Bangor, although I very much expected first of the week that I should. I thought I would not write that I was coming home; and so take you somewhat by surprise; but now I do not know when I may get a chance to go.
I got through on the Vermont & Mass. R.R. about the 15th  or 17th Inst. For a week or two before I got through, I had little to do but ride round on the Rail Road, perhaps be down at Fitchburg every day, settling up & arranging matters with the Contractors with whom I had to do to Fitchburg, be there in "business hours" and go back at night! Ride one hundred or one hundred & fifty miles per day.
I went to Royalston and spent one Sabbath, March11th. Folks pretty well there. Uncle same as ever. His new wife is a large fine looking woman, I do not judge however that she is in every respect a quite Equal to his last wife. Samuel is at home, and apparently doing nothing. He is a little inclined to be one, of that large class of "Soured Men"
Completed

2
He has been disappointed, unfortunate, & affected, perhaps. He and his father, I judge, have done so much that did not profit. They have done & not increased, and seem others increase by not doing. apparently, so that he has become sort of discouraged about doing any thing Seems to be contented to do nothing; which is, rather an unhappy state for any one. He had no family. no excitement to stimulate him to exertion. Josiah has been unfortunate, sick, or rather lame all Winter. Had the Dysentery last Fall, which left him with a weak knee so he could not walk all Winter; could not teach or do any thing. Is lame yet though he is better so he has been teaching for four weeks. Strange the chap will do so. He will probably never enjoy good health. He is undoubtedly an excellent Teacher. but he is killing himself. He must teach, he cannot lift his hand to do any work, rest of sentence in fold of paper? He was at home the Sat. night I was there.
Mrs. Brewer, Harriet Prescott's Widow, died in Worcester some three or four weeks since. Those Children, The Oldest "Harlan", and a lovely boy he is too, Uncle, you know, has adopted for his own. The other two a boy & girl, younger, by Mrs. Brewer's death are thrown back upon him. He feels poor, and that he has done enough for other people & their children, I suppose. He says he will try to get places for the children, if he cannot; it is just as belongs to the other Grand parent to support them.  Old Mr. Jacobs who refuses to have any thing to do about it, unless compelled by Law. Strange some one out of so large a family cannot take those children, and bring them up. The thought struck me that Mrs. John Cutter of Exeter was the  very one, who could and ought to take one of those children. Do you suppose she would?  It is strange what a family that was. They say that there has been but one of the family on speaking terms with all the rest for several years, Mrs. Walker alone.
Completed

I forgot that I had not stated that Mrs. Upham, formerly of Exeter, Me. has been lately a nurse in Worcester, died there & was carried to Royalston just three weeks after Harriet's death. Joseph Upham was at school at Brattleboro, when she died.
I went to Church at Royalston, Rev. Norman Hazen preached very well. Mr. Perkins does not attend Church: had not since Dr. Batchller's death.  Which you know was very sudden, of Apoplexy: affected him much.  I saw Mr. Silas Heyhood at Church. very glad to see me, as well as others.  I staid night at Mr. Goddard's. 

The next Saturday night I went over to Warwick, having got through with Vt. & Mass. R.R. and spent the Sabbath. Went up to Aunt Conant's after Church. It was good wheeling every where else but in Warwick, snow drifts so deep, they could not get to wheeling. Uncle C. grows more deaf. Aunt is very well. and the rest, except little Lucy has a cough.  It takes those folks a great while to live a little. Why I can live about as much in half a day as they do in a month. Aunt Conant had been writing you, and made haste to finish off the letter to send by me. as I am not likely to get home just yet. I send it, Monday last, 19th. I started for Home. Left Warwick early. stopped at Northfield to say good bye, and at Grouts. Spent most of the day at Fitchburg. Did some think I would go to Royalston. Mrs. Clark of Lanesville Ohio, Coz. Jerusha. was at Warwick when I was at Royalston, & at Royalston when I was at Warwick: came on alone, or with some of her children. She wanted to see me: probably remembered me, if I did not her. I would have gone out of the way considerable; but I was in a hurry to get home, and it would hinder me a day.
Completed

4
Isaac
March 25 1849
I was going to Worcester thence to Woonsocket and Providence, then Boston. But when I got to Groten, feeling in a hurry to go home: I went right through to Boston. Not liking the idea of reamaining idle a season or a year or two, I thought, though with very little prospect of any success, for I knew many had tried there, that I would come up to Manchester where a new Rail Road was just starting towards Winsor, Vermont, and see if there was any prospect of my even getting a situation on that. Manchester is a City and a fine great new place, mostly Factories, Boarding Houses & stores, 2500 Factory Girls. I spent one rainy day there; went into a Cotton Mill, as I had not before for some ten or twenty years. The Machinery for Cotton Mill is quite a sight, especially to an Engineer.

  There appeared so little prospect for me that I was on the very point, without going out to see Mr. Chase, the Chief Engineer of the Road in question; of starting off the other way by Stage, across from Manchester towards Portsmouth, to see on the way at Epping, a brother Engineer., Talbot of P. & C. R.R. who with his wife are particular friends of mine. Thence I was going to Portland and to see if there was any prospect for me in any of the Maine Rail Roads.

After some hesitation, I decided it did seem like throwing away a few dollars of expenses, I would come out and see Mr. Chase.  Reading some splendid recommendations I had from Mr. Field etc. with whom Mr. Chase was acquainted he thought I was perhaps not the man he wanted.
Completed

Jonesboro, Union Ci. Illinois
                                                                                                        Sabbath Eve. Oct. 19. 1851

Dear Mother & Sister Lucy
Brother Eliab & Samuel  

                            I do not know as I have really any thing to write, either new or important. It is very lately that I wrote to all o you, and told all I knew.

However it is Sabbath Evening, only nine oclock, I am not yet sleepy; but here in my own quiet room, with convenient pen ink & paper silently inviting me to write.

 I had just returned from Methodist Meeting. It is the custom here to have one service at 11 A.M. and usually only one in the day. If another at all it is in the evening. The people do not sat "Meeting" or "Church" but "preaching" I have been to "preaching" twice today, Morning to the Baptist, Night to Methodist. These two are the only denominations here. There are I think no Presbyterians in Union Co. The Lutheran and German Reformed both are occasionally met with through this part of the state. This today is the first preaching of the New Methodist Minister. You know they change every year, and in this state it comes just now. In some respects I do like the Methodists, far better at any rate than the Baptists. Their peculiar organization is certainly an effective one.
Completed

Well, I am getting along very well with the responsible duties of my situation as in charge of Division No. One, Ad interim.
Very pleasantly I have for along one week; though some of the duties devolving upon me appeared by no means pleasant. The former Div. Eng. left many matters of business and finance in very bad condition, which I had to arrange. There were many jarring interests and bad feelings previously engendered existing among the Subordinates. A number of these subs, my instructions made it my duty to discharge and dismiss from the service of the Company.  However I have succeeded in getting along very pleasantly with all parties, and I presume should have no difficulty as long as the money left me by the Chief should hold out.
My health is now excellent: had improved very rapidly. My appetite is enormous. I had become very thin, weighed but little over 150. but am now fatting up every day; and my strength increases in due proportion I believe.
Three days of last week I spent in riding about, and shall probably considerable part of this week.  I have got one of the very easiest of ambling or pacing nags for a saddle horse; It is quite a pleasure to ride on it - even all days.
The situation, which I did not get, of Division Engineer was even better pecuniarily than I had supposed. The Salary is $3000.00 per annum. Now that is quite a respectable Salary, is it not?
Completed

Especially in this country where expenses of almost every kind are comparatively low. Much lower at least than in cities.
In fact my present pay, of something over $1500, per annum is very tolerably, or would be if one could live in any decent country meanwhile.
It would make quite an income for any professional man only a few years out of College.
I have got a little bag of half Eagles saved up already which I wish were well deposited some where to be on interest.
I got a letter from Alfred L. Holman yesterday. two months & more on the route from Minnesota here by way of Milo.
The poor fellow was rather homesick there I reckon. He has bought land there, but works for Mr. Furber. Says he was green for going.

 Well I guess I will write no more tonight, except to ask you to write,

Good bye & Good bye

                                                                                         I.S.

P.S. Seems to me you have not written since getting back to Bangor. This letter you will perceive is for most of you in particular & Affectionately

                                                                                        I.S.M.
Completed

June 54
Dear Brothers & Sister

      And especially all of you
 This small peice of of a letter is hereby written to you particularly especially, and on purpose; not that I have really any thing to write or say, or that I have not already written enough already today; but simply to call your most benevolent attention to the fact of my lonely & desolate condition out here in Egypt all alone, in the hope & trust that your charity & compassion - your humanity even, will lead you to occasionally write a few lines of a letter to this bereaved & afflicted individual. knowing the consolation to be desired from a timely Epistle.

Most undeniably

                 Isaac S. Metcalf

DuQuoin, June 11. 1854
Completed

My Very Dear Nettie

 I am anxious and troubled about you. Have you decided the great questions? Have you determined to try with His help always to love and serve the Lord Jesus Christ? You know that it is the right thing to do - the only thing to do. - essential to peace and happiness now. - and forever.

You can do it any time. No one can do it for you. And now is the time. As I have tried to tell you before "Now is the accepted time." Delay is dangerous. It is making yourself unhappy, and hurting all your friends.
And every delay, every putting it off, makes it harder and harder to do.

 Oh Nettie, Nettie, I ask you, by the love of Christ, by the worth of your own soul, by every possible motive,( for all are really on the same side), to decide aright and at once.                                                                                            Father.
Completed

Dear Nettie

  Excuse may carelessness in not getting you this yesterday.

I did forget it.
All Well.

                                                                              Sincerely
                                                                                   Father

Miss Antoinette

  You were reading Shakespeare. Have you ever seen this Book. Mrs. Jameson's Characteristics of Women? You may find it interesting to compare the developement of some of Shakespeare's characters with their delineations by this author.

Of so, you will give me great pleasure by accepting the book.
A year or two since when my sister was reading Shakespeare, I procured her a copy of Mrs. Jameson's 'Characteristics', and got this for myself, in order to enjoy a mutual examination of some of the characters, writing to one another our observations and reflections. And we were very much pleased with it.
All things in it, as in Shakespeare itself, may not be exactly to my taste, or to yours; but it contains much thought and well expressed.
We cannot always in this world find only that with which we can fully agree.  May we not therefore, in reading and study, as we are obliged to do
Completed

in life generally, accustom ourselves to select and profit by the true and the good, while we pass uninjured by the false and the ill? Must we not so do in reading, I had almost said, all books but one. At any rate, we should cultivate the habit of such discrimination; lest we be like the Sponge. absorbing every thing it finds. Or is that the best example, only taking care to confine it to the purest possible?
Miss Antoinette

 I have been much pleased with your character, more and more so, the more I see and know it. I have wanted to become better acquainted. On that account, more than any other, I regret that I am probably about leaving New Hampshire, or this vicinity.
  May I hope that our acquaintance may still continue and increase?

I dare not think that I have pleased you, as you have pleased me. I have not the capacity of making myself readily understood. I have been perhaps too busy, all my life, in work or study, to have acquired ease of manners or habits of pleasing. My conversation and my manners are perhaps but half formed.
I believe however there is a warm, true heart with in for those who can find and stir its depth. a heart as yet unscared and uncontaminated by the accidents of life. Antoinette, may I not
Completed

say dear Antoinette; I know you are too good and kind to laugh at me for this; will you not forgive me, and think kindly of me, and invite me to see you, and write to you, and - thank you?

                               I.S. Metcalf

Jan. 17. 1850

Isaac Greenfield Mass.
Feb. 21 1850 
Dunbarton

                                                                                                Greenfield, Mass. Feb. 21. 1850

Dear Antoinette

     I am very thankful for the permission to write to you, and have now an occasion to avail myself of it which I gladly embrace. I told you I thought I should be back this week. I am obliged to deny myself that pleasure.

I thought then to complete my business for the present with the N.H. Central R.R. on Saturday, but was obliged to be in Manchester Monday and Tuesday.  Coming round here, I find it difficult getting away without stopping a day or two with my old superior Engineer, Mr. Field, whom I was much attached.
I want to visit my Uncle and relatives in Warwick, and now intend to go out there tomorrow and remain there over the Sabbath. My friends there were very kind to me while I was in Massachusetts, and always, and now that I am for once out of business, are inclined to insist upon a visit.
I shall probably be back in New Hampshire next
Completed

week, and shall as certainly see Dunbarton, which I believe has become the great point of attraction to me.
It is most likely that I shall remain in N.H. the coming year. I have nothing to do there at present, but the Directors of our Centra;l R.R. have expressed a great anxiety that I should not engage myself on any other Road. and have communicated their wishes to me so very flatteringly that I could hardly refuse. If they succeed in going on with the Road, I can do better there probably than any where else.

 But I shall be too late for the Mail if I write longer.                             Most Sincerely
                                                                                                             I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Portland Maine, March 11. 1850

Dear Antoinette

   I wanted to go to Dunbarton after getting back from Newport, but could not very well. Arriving at Parker's Friday night, I was obliged to be in Manchester on Saturday, and my time both day and evening was pretty fully occupied.  This morning I started by the early train in haste to get home tomorrow, for I have not heard one word from my brother since I left Bangor, now about a month ago. We had a very pleasant journey to Newport and back. I started with John Parker, but rode part of the way in company with Mr. Steele and others of the Rail Road Directors to point out to them the Route and Line of our Survey which the others were unacquainted with. They all seemed to think it quite essential that I should remain to attend to the Location and construction of this part of the Road. I had on the way some delightful visions of a snug little cottage in one of those quiet villages, made happy by a sweet and loving wife, as my home and Earthly Paradise for a year or two at least.
 I spent thirty six hours in Newport, much of it in explaining to members the proposed Rail Road Route, with the Plan, and the Estimates of the Report, with which I was of course more familiar than any one else. In this way I performed my part rather better and more profitably than by an attempt at set speeches.
Completed

The day Thursday was a very unfavorable one for the Meeting at Newport. The Storm undoubtedly prevented the attendance of hundreds. Still there were more probably three or four hundred present, and there seemed to be a very good degree of interest. I do not know what the eventual success of the present movement may be, but it is a very hard time to raise money, especially for the Railroads, and I am a good deal afraid they will not be able to go on this Season. If they do not, I shall of course be out of business in New Hampshire, and may be obliged to go West, or at least out of New England for employment.
I do hope they will be able to go on, on my own account, as well as on that of the Rail Road.
I think I can do better there than almost any where else, having a great advantage on acquaintance and the good will. It seems very important too that the Road should be built through immediately.

  I think I will send you a copy of our Report. You will notice my name favorably mentioned. It is all I wanted or could expect, although almost the whole Report, with the single exception of that paragraph was prepared and written by me and I made up all the Estimates etc. myself. They were all approved by Mr. Chase exactly as I formed them.

Yet the Credit, as a matter of course and custom. goes to the Chief Engineer, who is responsible for the whole.  However expect to be Chief Engineer myself one of these days.
Completed

But the Evenings are short when one does not get supper till eight oclock; it is getting late, and I must stop.
May I not expect to receive a letter from you at Bangor. where I shall probably remain for a week or two, at least.
My kindest regards to the family, and love to yourself.                             Yours truly

                                                                                                                       I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Isaac   Milo Maine
March 28 1850
Dunbarton                                                 Milo Maine. March 17. 1850
Dear Antoinette

             Your kind letter was joyfully received a day or two since. I was indeed glad to hear from you, that you were still well and happy. I did not get your letter until more than a week after it was mailed, on account of my change of place. My sick brother has moved here, where one elder brother resides, and where Mother makes it her home mostly.  If he remains as at present he will probably spend the Summer here. I wish of course to be with him as  much as possible, and shall probably remain here most of the time while I am at leisure. My poor Joseph does not get better. He can walk about the room a little, a cane in one hand, and taking hold of some one with the other, but can hardly get over a hearth, rug or an ordinary threshold between rooms. We wheel him about from one room to another in a large Easy chair with three wheels, or I take him up in my arms and carry him about as one would a child. What an affliction it is for a young man; one too of such ambition, such activity,  and such prospects of success. It seems indeed cutting one off from life in the midst of his days. It is wonderful how well he bears it and commands himself; always perfectly uncomplaining. cheerful, even merry. I spend the time mostly in reading, studying, and talking with him, varying it occasionally by a game of Chess or a promenade through the house. I should never tire of his society and conversation.
Completed

I have been here a little more than a week; came here a week ago last Saturday. I do not know how it is in New Hampshire, but Winter still continues here. The Weather is mostly cool, windy with frequent snow squalls; so the snow, which is two or three feet deep, hardly seems to diminish much. At Bangor however the snow is all gone and has been for a long time. Here it is good sleighing.

 I have been somewhat interested in religious affairs in this Town of Milo. The Congregational Church is very small and weak; only two acting, resident Male Members, and perhaps half a dozen females. Several of the Older Members have died within a few years, and all the younger ones moved away. The Males are both Old Men. No preaching. Yet they keep up their regular meetings, Society meetings they call them; and really interesting meetings they are too. Some of the Baptists usually come in with them. The Meetings, by the way, are held in a school house, or the Sons of Temperance Hall. Old Deacon Lee  a gentleman of much intelligence and education, formerly of wealth and political influence, and now I think one of the very best of Men, conducts the meetings with a dignity, propriety and fervency rarely seen; calling however upon some one of the younger men present. having lost in some measure his own voice and strength, to read the sermon, usually selected from the National Preacher; at any rate always a very excellent one. When I am present, as I have been for two Sabbaths now, the Old gentleman calls upon me to read. I do like to read before that little audience. I am really interested in these meetings. They must be beneficial. I cannot but think that God will sometime bless this little Church, feeble and afflicted as they have been. Their spirit of fervent prayer, and
Completed

their appreciation of the priveleges they do enjoy might well shame many a stronger and more prosperous church. I wish the Goffstown people could see their standing and priveleges in the same light. It might benefit some.

 My Sister, two Brothers, and myself united with this Church in Milo several years since, when we were all in this Town for a while. My Brothers and Sister soon transferred their connection to Bangor; and I have been away all the time myself. I do not think I have communed with this Church more than two or three times since I joined it; although I have never been in situation to remove my connection to any other Church. This I think has been injurious o me; attending meeting from Church to Church, and hardly feeling at home any where. The care and watchfulness of one's brethren are always needed by a young man. I suppose we all need the good influences exerted upon us by the Society and communion of the good.
  I believe I need a gentle companion, kind and good, whose constant influence, restraining from ill and prompting to all good, shall be a daily sunshine, gladdening and fertilizing my heart.  Such a companion I hope now to have as soon as I can get my self regularly established in some convenient position.
  I have yet heard nothing decisive from the New Hampshire Central, and it is yet uncertain where I shall go, or where I shall be this coming season. I do hope the N.H. Central will be able to go forward and complete their Road. It must be pleasanter and better for me in almost every respect. I certainly do not want to have to go out of New England for Employment.
Completed

There are openings in different directions, none to be sure exactly suiting me; but I do not want to decide definitely until they come to come conclusion about the N.H. Central.
I may leave here immediately upon the receipt of letter any time; and I may remain here for some time longer.  At any rate letters addressed to me either here or at Bangor will be sure to reach me without very much delay: and I hope you will write again very soon. I think you must have had a very pleasant journey, which you wrote of. You said Mrs. Parker and Mrs. Chase had been up to Dunbarton. How did you like Mrs. Chase? Mrs. Frances Chase, was it, a large lady? It seems you are going to teaching school again. I want to hear whether you decide to teach in Goffstown.
But I must close this long letter.

                                       Most truly Yours
                                                                       I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Milo, Maine, April 16, 1850

Dear Antoinette

  Your letter was received yesterday with much pleasure. It seems you have now been teaching in Goffstown for four weeks. It is quite a large school too it appears, much large than I supposed they could raise in that District.  I am afraid it will fatigue you too much. Hardly any thing is more wearing than school teaching to one to one who really feels its great responsibilities. You must remember that even as a school teacher you owe paramount duties to your self, to preserve your own health and strength unimpaired. We may sometimes be too apt to forget that, where we see clearly our duties to others.
  I should think you might have quite a pleasant school in that neighborhood, although I am not much acquainted except with the Parkers. I always found though that there were unpleasant as well as pleasant things in every school. There will be some cases where our best efforts to benefit seem to fail, and we are pained to see our labor in vain. The pleasure however of seeing good seed springing up and bearing fruit in one mind will however repay one for many disappointments.
  My time has been passing very quietly here, enlivened a little lately, perhaps saddened, by the prospect of leaving soon. I want to stay as much as possible with my
Completed

Brother. I did think some of going to New Hampshire last week. But the prospects upon the N.H. Central R.R. have not been very encouraging; and I have lately received quite a favorable offer from another quarter.  This is a situation upon the St. Andrews and Quebec RailRoad in New Brunswick, with the charge of twenty miles o Rail Road and a salary amounting to nearly twice as much as my pay upon the N.H. Central. I have hardly known what it was best to do about it. I dislike to go don there on some accounts I should much prefer to stay in New Hampshire if that Corporation could succeed in overcoming their difficulties and go on and complete their Road immediately. But their success in this is rather uncertain, although they wrote somewhat encouragingly to me. If they should fail. after my waiting a month or two longer. I might find it difficult to get business to suit me. I have also the promise of a situation on the Atlantic & St. Lawrence by and by: but still it is uncertain and if obtained would be less profitable.

I may decide not to go down to New Brunswick. The place was first offered to a friend of mine now in New York. He could not leave, and wrote at once to get me to go, and the chance certainly seems a very favorable one in many respects.

Negociations are now going on about it.
How should you like to go down to New Brunswick, and live awhile among those Canadian French, and "Blue Noses,"  as they call them here? I should not like to go alone.
They want me however to commence operations on the Road about the first of May.
Completed

Now Antoinette you must advise me whether to go to New Brunswick or not. I have advised you, you know about school teaching.  One must naturally expect to feel there a lack of some of our New England social and religious priveleges. But opportunities of usefulness might be none the less: and it is a situation in some respects very desirable.

I may conclude to go down to St. Andrews next week to see the chance, and make arrangements about it, and then come back to Bangor again.
I am glad to hear of Mr. Willey's doing well. I have felt a good deal for him.; he has many trials and discouragements. He told me once he thought there was not much sympathy of feeling between him and his people. I really do not think he has a very encouraging field of labor.  I hope that the people of Milo are to have some preaching this Summer. My Brother has written to the Home Missionary Society,  and it is thought they will send a Missionary here for a while at least.

  My Brother remains about the same. If any thing he grows slightly weaker. I do not know how he will bear my going away. I sometimes wish to stay and spend the summer with him.
I should like to see your Rose bush again. It has certainly recovered very rapidly.  The Weather here has been very cold and the Spring extremely backward. Many of the favorite haunts of the wild flowers that I remember years ago, are now buried in snow.      
  I hope I shall have the pleasure of hearing from you again soon.
                                                                 Yours Truly
                                                                         Isaac Stevens Metcalf
Completed

Milo, Maine, May 13, 1850

Dear Antoinette

  Your letter was received with much pleasure a week since. I thought then that I should go to New Hampshire this week, but it seems probable now that I shall not.

I have not been down to New Brunswick, and now hardly think that I shall, although the matter is not yet fully decided.  I can hardly make up my mind to leave my brother now for any account. He is worse, and growing worse: seems to be growing weaker and weaker every day. He is now almost entirely helpless, cannot raise himself at all, hardly move a hand or a foot without assistance.
His mind is still active and cheerful; but he can hardly bear the idea of my leaving him at all, and indeed I can hardly think of it myself. Some one must be with him constantly. Mother is not strong enough to lift him alone. Brother Eliab cannot leave his business in Bangor at present, and it is unpleasant to leave him to be taken care of by Strangers.  The Affliction seems hard enough for the poor fellow to bear with all possible alleviations. I thinks he feels any lack of the society of his own family more than most persons would.
Completed

This week and last week I suppose you are enjoying at home, "quiet Dunbarton." You must enjoy it after the fatigue and the various vexations of School-teaching.  I have wanted very much to call in upon you now while you are at home. You may be assured that not a day, hardly an hour, passes, that I do not think of it. Sometimes I think I will go at any rate. but it hardly seems to do, and I am obliged to deny myself the privelige.

  It is a delightful season of the year, sunny skies, springing grass and flowers, singing birds; any one seems almost inexcusable who cannot have at least a heart full of melody.  Perhaps my hearts contains as much of it as any one's, if it does fail of finding an expression upon the tongue.

Next week you will be teaching again. I should think the Spring time the Season when it would be most unpleasant to teach. Will you not find it irksome to be confined to a schoolroom these bright Spring days. and in hot and languid June? Will you not some days sympathize with the little ones when they play truant? "To continue ten or eleven weeks" Well I hope it will be the last of your school teaching.

  I thank you for remembering and thinking of our little meetings at Milo. Fortunately I am no longer called upon to supply the place of a Minister. A young man, a student in the Bangor Theological Seminary is now here, spending his vacation in Milo, as a Missionary.
I hope he may be the means of doing much good.
Completed

He is but just beginning to preach, but I think may make a very useful man. He seems to have the "root of the matter" in him. He has succeeded in getting out quite a congregation of attentive listeners. Mere talent is not the only or the principle thing required for the Minister. This young man is a son of Rev. Mr. Temple, the Missionary, at Smyna, I believe. We hope he is really doing good here. but we must feel, that it is of comparatively little account who plants, or who waters; it is God alone who must give the increase. The soil here is perhaps unpropitious. It has been run over first by Methodism, And then by the Wild fires of the "Christian connection" and Millerism in various forms. The subjects of these sects are now perhaps calling themselves Universalists or even Infidels. God can make even the dry bones live.
Mother and Sisters are quite anxious to see and become acquainted with you. No one had more to be thankful for in a good Mother than have I. Losing my father at so early an age I owe every thing to my Mother's influence. 'Her children rise up and call her blessed.' And my own Sister Lucy, now Mrs. Furber of Bangor,- I can tell you nothing about her - but she is "Our Lucy"!
There I believe I must stop writing for this time.
I hope to hear from your again soon. I shall want to hear about your school etc. - please direct to Milo until I will inform you where I go. Love and regard to your parents etc. I hope your Mother's health is improving. Yours Sincerely

                                                                                                                  I.S.M.

Isaac              Milo Maine
June 30 July 2, 1850
Dunbarton                                                                   Milo, Me. June 30. 1850
Dear Antoinette

                 Your letter was welcomed more than two weeks since. I intended to write before this time, but various matters in addition to my constant care of my brother have occupied my attention, and delayed it somewhat.

Sister Lucy I wrote to you was sick of a fever, and Mother went to Bangor to take care of her. As soon as Lucy was able to ride, she came up here with her husband and stayed a week, returning yesterday.  We enjoyed their visit very much, although Lucy was well enough to sit up only a part of the time. I think a sister never was more beloved than is ours. Joseph says that the best people in the world are not in Milo today. I believe he thinks they were yesterday.
Joseph remains just about the same. He failed very fast for a while, but for some four weeks past has seemed stationary: almost entirely helpless, but we have hoped getting no worse; and we have been encouraged lately to hope that he might gradually recover.
I have been very much confined here with my brother. I should think it must be two months since I have hardly been away from the house. I hardly leave him at all by day, and sleep near him at night being up to help him more, never less than twice, often
Completed

half a dozen times or more in the course of the night.
So my life is quite different from what it was last year, being so quiet in one place. It does not agree quite so well with me to be within doors all of the time, but my health is very good, and being up nights does not trouble me at all. And certainly I could not complain comparing my situation with my brother's. He never complains.

 I have thought of you some of the very warm says we have had lately, and wondered what kind of a school room you have. Most schoolrooms are not very comfortable places in hot weather. One feels the heat much more than in almost any dwelling house. I should think you Dunbarton home might be a comfortable place. You must be careful and not get fatigued and sick teaching this warm weather.

I should think from what you wrote that you must have a very pleasant school: that "sewing circle" must be extremely interesting.  School teaching will be very pleasant, if you can feel that you are constantly doing good, and that to the souls as well as to the intellects of your scholars.
Your father and Mother had rather an unpleasant time for their journey. For several weeks it rained most all of the time here, but for a few weeks past the weather is warm and pleasant enough.
I know you would be very much pleased with Botany. It is to be learned by practice rather than by study at school. It is excellent employment for Joseph. I usually go out
Completed

a little while in the morning while he sleeps and gather plants. We have several of the best books, and descriptions of plants, with which we compare, then describe any new ones, and preserve specimens.  The Botany of this region is quite various, and has never been much examined. Joseph says we shall be obliged to publish a Botany or "Flora" of "Cedar Grove"  Cedar Grove is a name given to this place from a beautiful grove of Cedar trees near the house.

 Joseph can do little but look, but he is much interested in our researches, and very thorough in his acquaintance with the vegetable world, or at least that part of it that he has ever seen.  I am very fond of Natural History in any of its branches. Viewing animated or vegetable nature as the work of God. the almost infinite manifestation of his benevolence and greatness, we may apply to them Dr. Young's celebrated saying about Astronomy. "The undevout Astronomer is mad." We may say the same of the Student of Natural history.
 You will be glad to hear that the good people of Milo are to have constant Evangelical preaching for the future.  Partly by the aid of the Maine Missionary Society, a graduate of Bangor Theol. Sem. is to preach here three fourths of the time, while a pretty good Free Will Baptist preacher is to occupy the other fourth of the time.

Mr. Temple who is here this week, and who boards with us, is very much interested in the state of things here. He thinks there have been eight or ten hopeful conversions within three months, among them two of Sister Almeda's children. Of course we rejoice
Completed

The interest still continues, I believe, though the work is very still, and without excitement.
It is principally among the young.
I am unable to attend Meetings at all, but seeing Mr. Temple every day, I hear of the progress.
Do you hear anything of the state of Religion in Goffstown since you left there?

 Your brother, I suppose, is not at home this summer. It is probably a busy season with him.  I hope he is prospering.
  This is a very hurried and careless letter but I believe it must draw to a close.

Please give my love and respect to your father and Mother.  I wish I could call into your school room this afternoon, and then walk home with you. I believe I think of you all the oftener for being so closely confined here.
I hope you will write very soon, and above all do not wish to make your sheet 'shorter.'

                                                                                                       Sincerely yours
                                                                                                                 I.S.

Isaac  Newberry N.H.
July 28, 1850
Dunbarton                                                                Newbury N.H. July 28. 1850
Dear Antoinette

  I have just returned from Newport, where I have been to Church. It is nearly ten miles from here, but it appeared the best thing I could do, though I could have found a Baptist meeting within five miles in another direction, and Universalist much nearer. I was a little disappointed in the preaching though. I expected to hear Old Mr. Woods, a regular old school preacher, sound and old-fashioned-ly learned. I really like to hear him preach. But a young man, who is about to be settled as Colleague to Mr. Woods, preached, and as I thought not so well.
I am very anxious to hear from your brother, and I hope soon to hear from you that he is much better, and moreover that neither yourself or you Mother have made yourselves sick in taking care of him.  I should perhaps in my anxiety to hear from your brother & yourself have written before if I could have found time. You can hardly imagine how busily I am employed or how great a weight of care and responsibility I have upon me.

We breakfast at five. I must be in the field with the Party all day long till dark; then I have perhaps some hours of calculations etc. to go through with, perhaps while
Completed

while the others are asleep.  And my mind is so filled with curves and cuttings, and Tunnel that I could hardly get my thoughts to myself even today on the Sabbath.  They have put me in a very difficult position, too difficult for so young an Engineer. I told Mr. Steele that they ought at least to get up here since old celebrated Engineer to consult upon this spot, but he said that they had put confidence in me! I am afraid it speaks ill for their wisdom!
For my own part, I shall get used to it, and it will come easier by and by.  It is a great deal of work to "break in" a new party; to teach each one his business, how to do it, and how to do it well & rapidly.

I think I shall get an excellent party in the end;  and then I can teach them to do many things that I am now obliged to do myself.
  I am vexed that I was obliged to make such a visit at Dunbarton as I did. It was altogether too bad.  I hope your Mother will forgive me; and I am certainly thankful to her for her suggestions. It was as my own Mother would have spoken. What did your Father say upon my Sunday visit? You must intercede for me with him.
     I have not heard from my Brother, or from home, since I came from there: so that I am in almost a very fever of impatience to hear from them. I have written twice, and must write again this evening. I could not at first write to them exactly where to
Completed

direct letters to, and they may have written to Goffstown or Henniker, and so I have not got the letters yet.

 I do hope you will let me hear from you soon I want to hear from your brother's health.
 I do not know but I must stop, or have no time to read or think today.
 Do not make my hasty letter a guide in writing if you have time to write more. You would excuse me and this if you know how little time I have. I do not like to write letters on the Sabbath, but I must write to Joseph, and also to Lucy today.
  My love to Henry and your Parents, with a kiss to yourself   Truly yours

Isaac  Sunapee Newport} N.H.
Aug. 11 1850

                                                                                       Sunapee, N.H. Aug. 11. 1850

Dear Antoinette

     Your kind letter was received with much pleasure more than a week since. I intended to write before this time, but have been unable to. My time, from quite early in the morning until about dark, is spent in the field. The evenings are quite short, but must be spent, perhaps lengthened out somewhat, with two or three to help me in "Office Work", calculations, drafting etc.  So that my time is entirely occupied. Moreover, though abundant showers to wet us occasionally there have been no rainy days, no day when we did not work out of doors, since we have been here. So that I have really no time to write letters except on the Sabbath, therefore I do not write letters except after I get home from Church, one every week to brother Joseph, and perhaps one or two in the evening to yourself and my Mother or sisters. I have a good distance to go to Church besides; out to Newport. The distance is less however today than before, for we moved our boarding place yesterday, from the End of the Lake in Newbury up to "Angels" in Sunapee. "Sunapee" is a new name for the town. It was changed from Wendall to Sunapee this summer. I still however have my letters my letters directed to Newbury. as we shall be here probably but a little while, and can get any thing very readily from Newbury.

We shall soon be out at Newport for a few weeks and then back again to Newbury & Bradford.
Completed

You say I must be careful of my health. I intend to be so. I have learned I think to realize the importance of health more than I formerly did. Being with my brother I think has taught me some thing in that respect.  My health has always been so good that I have thought little of it, and have been perhaps unnecessarily careless of my self sometimes. I intend to "take it easy" now. I have certainly a great load of care and responsibility, but I do believe with you that "Life's cares are comforts", or at least that they are necessary to our happiness.
 I was very sorry to hear that Henry was no better when you wrote, I hope he has at least begun to recover before this time, and that I shall soon hear of his rapid convalescence. It must be quite a trial to you to be teaching away from home while he is so sick as he was when you wrote.

Has Henry had any other Medical advice since he came home than your Dunbarton physician? When a friend is very sick I cannot be contented without wanting the best advice that can be obtained. You know the proverb that in the Multitude of counsellors there is wisdom.

 Brother Joseph they think at home is still recovering but very slowly indeed. I have had two or three letters from there since I last wrote to you. I did not hear sooner because their letters were at first directed to Henniker. I have also a man here in my party from there, an acquaintance of our folks who left there last week after seeing Joseph.
  I am very glad to hope that I am forgiven for my breaking the Sabbath the day that I was at Dunbarton. I am certainly very much obliged to your
Completed

Mother for her kind advice and shall be very grateful if she will always favor me in the same way. It will give me the benefit of having two Mothers.

  You wrote of the unpleasant showery weather, and enquired whether we always found Shelter. I will tell you how we do when it rains when we are away in the woods or fields, at a distance from houses. - We take off our coats to wrap over and protect the Instruments, that is, if it rains so hard that handkerchiefs etc. do not shield them enough, and then stand ourselves and receive the full benefit of the shower!  Some would think this very bad, and perhaps expect colds etc. as a result; but you know I am a "Cold Water Man", and think a good Wetting is a Shower, or by wading a Stream or some pond, as we do occasionally, is a benefit.
    That which you reserved to the last in your letter is indeed rejoicing. How happy such a state of mind in your dear brother must make your family circle. The rejoicing - such a family circle in such circumstance is like the rejoicing in heaven. May Henry live long to prove life a gain to himself. and a gain to friends, and to the world.

But it is getting quite late and I must stop - with my love to all the family, Yourself & Henry in particular.

                                                                                       Yours truly
                                                                                                 I.S. Metcalf
Completed
