Isaac  Newport N.H.
Sept. 1 1850
Dunbarton 

                                                                                                  Newport N.H. Sept. 1 1850

Dear Antoinette

                      Two of your kind letters lie before me. The first, by some mistake in the Post Office, although the direction was perfectly plain, came here from Newburyport Mass. whether it was missent, and long out of its way.

The other which informed me of your heavy affliction was received yesterday. I had feared a fatal termination of Henry's disease after hearing that he remained so long without improvement. The Hand of God has indeed come very near. It must come with an almost stunning weight upon you all.

   How happy you are in having such a hope even in his death. You can feel as well as know that - 
                                      "He doeth all things well"

Truly the bitterest sting of Death, and the greatest victory of the Grave are not. You can feel that in this harsh sundering of the ties of Earth, severe and painful as it must be, - as our very Nature makes it - you can feel that then is "one more added to the attractions of Heaven" "The far country, towards which we journey, seems nearer & nearer to us, and the way less dark, for that thou hast gone before, passing so quietly to thy rest."

   In your sorrow, you can sorrow not for hum. The affliction and the loss are great gain for him. and doubtless designed for good to others.

[left-hand side] We came out to Newport to board the first of last Week, shall probably remain here a few days longer, and then go out to Newbury, or quarter ourselves a while as before, among the farmers between here & there.
Completed

We believe that all the afflictions and trials of life, dark and mysterious as they may seem, are designed for our best and highest good. We should see in them all the hand of Him whose kindness never forgets our true interests in any of its dispositions.
We in our shortsightedness can not understand why one in whom were garnered so many hopes, and so much of promise, should be called so suddenly away from opening fields of usefulness on Earth. but we can realize that God who knoweth all things know it best, and must meekly bow before his chastising rod.
Henry's death may be sanctified as the means of much good among the young people of Dunbarton.
May all profit by the warning dispensation. In sympathizing, as I hope I do, with you, in your affliction, may my heart be softened, and drawn nearer to God.

   I have just now come from Church and the Communion. I have not had the privelige of attending Communion before, for six months. This was a very interesting occasion. Two young ladies were admitted to the Church, and Old Mr. Woods is really very impressive. I do like him very much of a preacher, and it was quite a relief to me to have the young Man who has been preaching here leave. Mr. Woods is certainly a superior man, one whose equals are rare in any place. Added to undoubted talent and learning, he has an unusually good voice, and a very impressive manner.
Completed

Last Sabbath, I was out here in the rain, Mr. Woods was absent and his pulpit was filled by a young Episcopal Clergyman, a native of Newport, but for many years absent. He went through all the Episcopal Service etc. He had a very fine voice, agreeable manner, and considerable ability. People here appeared to be much pleased with him, but I learn since that he is a Southern Slaveholder!

If I had known this fact at the time, it would have detracted something from my enjoyment perhaps. or at any rate wounded some of my antislavery feelings. 

            Evening. I have just returned from the Monthly Concert. Mr. Woods gave a very interesting account of the Meetings last week at Great Falls. He mentioned particularly Pres. Lord's Sermon, the "Concis ad Clerum". Pres. Lord, you know, advances some peculiar views upon the Second Coming of Christ which it appears were touched upon in this sermon. Dr. Dwight of Portland, who preaches in the course of the meeting upon a somewhat similar topic, probably presented a little different view of the subject. Mr. Woods spoke of Mr. Stoddard, Missionary among the Nestonians, who was present, as very interesting. I was glad to hear that Mr. Willey of Goffstown was appointed Secretary of the N.H. Bible Society.

It has seemed to me that Mr. Willey has hardly a fair field for his peculiar qualities where he now is at Goffstown.
You asked me in one of your letters if I did not feel almost as much wearied on the Sabbath as on other days.
Completed

I have sometimes thought that I felt fatigue more on that than on any other day. The endeavor to unbend the mind from the labors of the week seems to bring on a very unusual languor, and a sort of indisposition to engage in, or give my attention to any thing else; and if I stir myself up to active thought. there is a certain tendency to revert to the old Channels.

  You ask about my compensation from the N.H. Central R.R. When Mr. Steele wrote to me of the position with the care & responsibility the Directors wish to impose upon me, I wrote that I ought to have the rate of $1200, per year. and perhaps few perform such & so much service cheaper than that. He did not get my letter, but wrote again urging me to come. and I dd not learn the vote of the Directors limiting the Salary to be paid to $3.00 per diem, till I started. I told Mr. Steele that if I had known it I should not have come; but I cared much less for the compensation, except in name, than for the place, the responsibility, doing the work in short, and thus improving my capacities and reputation. They however gave me considerable advantages in other respects; furnishing me a good horse; paying expenses etc.

The amount of Salary allowed me has always been one of the least of my cares.
I had letters from home yesterday. Joseph remains about the same. They still hope he is recovering, but almost imperceptibly slowly. I usually write to him every Sabbath evening, but have not yet commenced.
Having now no other leisure I write to Joseph & Mother and to yourself on the Sabbath. I have always been in the habit of writing to Mother on the Sabbath.
But I must stop - hoping to hear from you again very soon.       Yours truly

                                                                                                         I. S.
Completed

Newbury Vt. Sept. 21. 1850
                                                                                                   At "Capt. Joe Morse's", Under Bald Sunapee Mountains

Dear Antoinette

    Having at last finished up my week's work, I joyfully seat myself to commence a letter to you. I always try very hard to get things all business a little earlier than usual on Saturday evenings. It is a habit I learned at Northfield and there about in Massachusetts, where many of the people commence their Sabbath at Sunset on Saturday Evening.
 This evening I have finished up, and put away my Field Books and Profiles before eight oclock. To be sure I was then very much tempted to go "'Coon hunting" The Mountains near us {it seems almost over the house,} abounds with Raccoons, and this beautiful moonlight evening their shrill hoot or whistle is heard to much advantage from the open window near which I am seated. I have never tried "Coon hunting", and had really considerable curiosity in that line. But there were some adverse circumstances in way of the sport.  to say nothing of the rough precipitous boulder covered hill sides upon which it must be prosecuted; and I soon decided upon the more quiet pleasure; though I have just been listening to one or two 'Coon' & ' Possum' stories pretty well told under my window by one of my men who spend several years at the South and West.
Completed

We are now boarding at an old Farmer's, a hard headed old fellow, who has dug out from among the rocks a valuable farm, in a little recess here among the Mountains, with their steep rocky sides stretching up apparently indefinitely in almost two sides
Our R.R. Line is obliged to wind into this recess some miles from Villages or high roads and it saves us a good deal of travelling to board in here for a week or two. They are Old fashioned people, plain and really coarse, but we get along very well here for a while. We are obliged to accustom our selves to all sorts of circumstances. The "Old Woman" here entertains us with accounts of old Log-house times when she had bears & wild cats for Neighbors, and tells what her "Old Man, he" did.
Well, some credit is is to be given to such people; they have made a fine place here from a wilderness of rocks and forests. and have prospered perhaps deservedly.

 We have been in here now almost a week. I shall find the way out tomorrow in some direction.
 Last Sabbath, going out to Newport, I was very much pleased with the Preacher I heard. It was a young man, Mr. Wellman of Cornish, just beginning to preach but certainly giving abundant promise of eloquence and even greatness. I was much pleased with the perfectly simple dignity, of his manner and style. Entirely free from Affectation so common in young men, and yet a natural consciousness of strength. I was much struck too by an extraordinary resemblance to a College friend of my own; the same heavy frame, broad sallow face, Massive head, and lofty brow.
Completed

with the very same deeply set dull grey eyes, dull as lead till they gradually kindle until you seem to see something away behind them brilliant indeed.

  I rejoice with you in the good news you write of your younger brother. How joyful it must be to you and your parents. May he truly have chosen that good part never to be taken away.
 It seems that you are still demanded as a School teacher; but I am glad that you have fully decided not to teach any more. You have certainly done your part of teaching and done it well.

Your last School was so pleasant, it was a very good one to leave off with. So the last impressions will be favorable, which is worth something any where.

    Can you excuse this hurried, and I fear carelessly written letter. I believe I am getting sleepy and must stop - if I do not find a chance to write more tomorrow sometime.

Do not be anxious about my health; it seems perfect. I believe I was never more strong & healthy.
My brother's health remains about the same. We hope he is gradually recovering. 
My respects to your family, and I hope to hear from you again very soon, even if I have not time to write any thing myself worth reading.

                                                                                                   Sincerely Yours
                                                                                                            I.S.M.
Completed

Isaac Bradford N.H
Oct. 14 1850
Dunbarton                                  Bradford N.H. Oct. 13. 1850
Dear Antoinette

 Your letter of Oct. 1st. I did not receive until two or three days since. We have been living in out of the way places along the propose RailRoad Line, but away from the Stage Road and did not get our letters etc. until we got out to Bradford. I do not know though but your letter gratified me almost enough when I did get it to compensate for the delay.

It would have pleased you to see how eager the whole party were for letters and news. I take a Boston Daily Newspaper, The Evening Traveller. We usually get it the next noon: but when we got out here and got those of a week or more together, it was worth while to see the rush and anxiety for news.
Today I am almost homesick. This place is almost heathenish. Here is quite a village for a country place, or rather two villages half a mile apart. There are two taverns, half a dozen stores, mills etc.; and likely to be two Railroads. One would expect two or three Churches at least. There is one miserable looking Meeting house, half way between the villages, but no minister: some sort of Baptist or 'Christian' preaching one half or one third of the time, and even then nobody hardly attends.  Today a strange Millerite, or Second Advent preacher, he called himself, from somewhere, held forth and part of the day at least drew large crowds of eager Audition, hoping to hear some new thing. The preacher was a young fellow of considerable shrewdness and considerable
Completed

command of language. It was really painful to hear the way in which he used scripture to support his theories. Sometimes one could hardly avoid being amused, in spite of the impiety I had almost said. Among other things I remember he entered into an argument upon Presdestination, or God's decrees. "Him, being delivered by the determinate counsel, and foreknowledge of God etc."
'I will allow the foreknowledge of God," said he, but the determinate counsel, he thought {or labored long to prove} was the Council or Sanhedrin of the Jews, firmly determined to put Christ to death! You will not thank me for that idea perhaps. But is it not sad to reflect upon the effect produced by such preaching. If it has any effect it must make people think that any thing can be proved from the scriptures, few being able to detect the fallacies of such arguments as many of them, and finally it must lessen or destroy all faith. I believe it has had that effect in many cases. It seems to have burned over the hearts of the people in some places like a wild fire, destroying the very roots of all religious feeling.
I was almost inclined to think today that some of my men who wish always to spend the Sabbath away in the woods, or climbing some mountain, might really spend it better than in hearing such preaching. I can really hardly blame those whom I know to be true lovers of Nature for such a choice: though I have never though it right to set such an example myself.
The lines you quote about the lover of Nature I have seen, I think, though I do not remember where. I have admired,
Completed

and I believe felt them. I believe I have a taste for Natural History in all its branches, though I have had but comparatively little time to devote to it. The birds were always among my dearest friends, and I am fond of almost every animal. It is one of the hardest things for me in my business to be so frequently obliged to pass by a plant which I wish to examine, or a bird I wish to watch. Even when busiest though, I frequently observe a plant which is new to me, and this summer have got in the habit of plucking such an one or a sprig of it, placing it hastily between the leaves of my Field Book, and sending it by my next letter to my brother. In this way all my letters to him are double letters, and he is so expert a Botanist that a sprig even will generally show him the place of a plant he has never before seen. In his next letter he writes his observations upon the plants I sent him; and this adds additional interest to our correspondence.

 I should think that the reciprocal visiting which you mention with your neighbors of Hopkinton must have been very & interesting. I hope it was profitable.

Simeon L.S. Burnham of Manchester is one of my Party, and the same I presume to whom you refer. He commenced with me here in July, I made him "Transit Man", he is active, intelligent, and well educated, and if he continues in the business, I think can do well as an Engineer.

 My Brother I hear from about every week: but I am getting extremely anxious to see him. If he is recovering it is very slowly: and I sometimes fear that he is not really much better. He is still almost entirely helpless.
Completed

You have heard the whistling of "Coons" then at the West. I never head them except about here.
I did not get any chance to go hunting. Perhaps it was hardly best, as I can get exercise enough in my business and should look to more quiet occupations for my relaxation, or recreation.

 You inquire when I shall be likely to emerge from these recesses. As long as my Party is in the Field, it is about impossible for me to get away even for half of a day. Any other one can be spared, but if I am absent all must stop. So you can see that I am really of some consequence in one place at least!

However I think we begin to see through and it is very possible that our out of door work here may soon be finished up for the present.
I am as yet though almost entirely ignorant of the plans of those who decide upon our advances. I do not know whether they will be able to proceed or not.

  But I must stop - it is half past ten o clock before I thought of it, and I am obliged to be an early riser, in these times.

My love to all, especially Antoinette

                                                                Sincerely I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Isaac  Manchester N.H.
Nov. 5 1850                                              Manchester N.H. Nov. 3. 1850
Dunbarton
Dear Antoinette

 It seems a long while since I heard from you. I think the last letter I received from you must have been written a month since. I have been for a fortnight past both wishing and expecting an opportunity to get to Dunbarton and yesterday felt really a good deal disappointed.

Two weeks ago Friday I came down to Manchester and Goffstown, and though to spend the Sabbath at Dunbarton, but found myself obliged to return to Bradford on Saturday.  The next week I was at Concord two or three days attending a "Hearing" before the Rail Road Commission, in which the N.H. Central was vitally interested.
Concord seemed so near Dunbarton that I wanted to get there, but could not get away either day or evening. When we got through at Concord, I had to return to Bradford to finish up my business there. Saturday afternoon I came down to Manchester again, but it rained so much that I was obliged to stay and spend the Sabbath. It was the first Sabbath I ever spent in Manchester! The past week I have been preparing "Estimates" of the amount of work and cost of building our route from Henniker to Newport. which Estimates are to be ready before the next meeting of the R.R. Commissioners Nov. 13.
I did think to get away yesterday afternoon, but the only consolation left for my disappointment is the opportunity of writing today. Perhaps a letter from you may be somewhere on the way for me now. When I left Bradford I expected to go to "Parker's" to do this Office Work, and directed my letters remailed thither.
Completed

I expect now to be at liberty before many weeks. The controversy between the N.H. Central and the Concord & Claremont is apparently about to be finally decided against the former; in which case, we shall have nothing to do but to stop at once, and do nothing above Henniker.
There has been considerable excitement about RailRoad matters lately. The Question of the Lease of the Manchester & Lawrence R.R, by the Concord R.R. has excited much interest; and its consummation is likely to weigh heavily against the N.H. Central.

 But my thoughts are running rather too much upon RailRoad matters for the Sabbath day. My mind is so full of 'RailRoad' all the week, that, without constant watchfulness, it will revert to the same topic even at times when it ought to be otherwise employed. Did you ever have your thoughts so long bent and fixed upon a single subject that it seemed to become a sort of natural channel for them? like a crooked spring the elasticity is all one way. I sometimes think of this. Perhaps it is in some measure necessary in almost any employment, any employment of the mind at least, but at any rate it ought not to be permitted to interfere with our proper attention to higher concerns and eternal interests.

Today in my second Sabbath in Manchester, I was in Manchester a good deal last year but never happened to stay here over the Sabbath. I hear Mr. Wallace preach, and like him very much. I was much pleased with his Sermons last Sabbath. I think he must be a large Minded Man, and one who might safely be called Eloquent at times. I have thought though from some things in his manner and style that he might have lacked some of the things which go to form a thorough education.
Completed

This forenoon his subject was "The Church", the text was Off I forget thee O Jersulem etc." ; And at times he was really Eloquent, as he dwelt upon the past sufferings & trials of the Church, its Excellencies, benefits, to the world, its standing, and its hopes. I have never heard any other minister of Manchester.

  I have not told you how I was disappointed about seeing my Sister, Sister Anne, who has been in Wisconsin for two years. She was coming home, and wrote to me that if I would be in Boston Saturday night I would meet her. It was two weeks ago yesterday. Being at Manchester I did not get the letter until I got back to Bradford. If I had received it in season I should have tried hard to go down. I wanted to see her very much, and perhaps if I had known it in season might have gone down to Boston by the evening train, Spent the Sabbath there, and returned by the early train Monday morning.
 However if we get through here soon, which now appears probable, I can go "Down East", and see her there, and my brother too, whom I am getting quite impatient to see again, especially as he remains so much the same. I am afraid that he is not really getting any better. They write to me that he seems stronger and better in some subjects, but does not appear to regain the use of his limbs. His hands and arms are exactly as weak and helpless as they were last Spring. One of them he can not use at all, and even the other he can with difficulty raise up to his head. Now I do want to see him!

There I fear I shall be late to Church. You must write to me here, and I hope too you will see me soon at Dunbarton. Sincerely yours  I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Isaac  Bangor Maine
Nov. 28, 1850
Dunbarton                                                                               Bangor Me Nov. 28, 1850
Dear Antoinette

                                                I have just received your kind letter. I am here in Bangor attending a RailRoad Meeting and with little time to write, but think I must if it be but little.

The Meeting here is for the organization of the Penobscot and Kennebec R.R. Co. Choice of Directorship. I thought it best to be present and have applied for a situation as Engineer; but there is very little probability of my obtaining it. There are too many applicants men more known, with more influence to favor them, and various advantages more than I can claim. Though to be sure, {you know how much one's self love influences the judgment} I could not help thinking that some of the Office seekers where real character and ability I know something of, might in fact be no more capable of rendering valuable service than myself.
There is little chance of my getting employment here, and I may be out of business for a long time. On some accounts I can hardly regret it, though I suppose I ought to be at work. I should like to spend the winter with my brother, if convenient. I hardly know whether to say he is better or worse. In many respects he seems better than when I left.
Completed

him last Summer; he is less easily fatigued, sit up nearly all the time, and bears excitement or motion better. But at the same time, his limbs are still weaker, more entirely helpless.
His Spirits are still good; his mind sustains himself, and all around him; as ever.
My sister, who, I believe I told you, had been very sick lately, is still very feeble. She did not seem to recover her health & strength as expected. We feared she would fall away in consumption; Oh how we feared! I cannot tell how dear "Our Lucy" is to us all. She seems to me almost an Angel here on Earth. This week we rejoice exceedingly in that she appears to be recovering finely.

 You had not heard from New Haven when you wrote. I mean to have written to you from Boston what I learned there; that Miss Bacon was delivering a course of lectures there etc. I rather think that her school was given up for a time at least! if  it has ever been revived? some time ago, a year or two. I did not think of it when at Dunbarton, but afterward remembered something about Miss Bacon's difficulty with a young clergyman, Rev. Mr. ~ I forgot the name.  Miss Catherine E. Beecher, perhaps you may have seen, has lately published a book, "Fact Stranger Than Fiction", I believe is the title. to vindicate the character of her friend, Miss Bacon.

I have not read this book, and know nothing of the merits of the case except from the various newspaper reports; but am inclined to believe that no blame could justly be attached to Miss B., possibly she was
Completed

indiscreet, or suffered herself to be too easily imposed upon. 
But the young man was wealthy & influential, too valuable a friend to Yale College to be lost, and so the Authorities supported him, and thought it was better that a single female should suffer than that the College should. If so it is certainly to be hoped that they will suffer in the end, and that justice will eventually be done.
Whether Miss Bacon's school has ever been revived I can not learn. If it has not been I suppose you will select the next best place you can find. But I must stop this hurried scrawl. I fear it is hardly legible, even if worth reading.

I am going to Milo tomorrow and hope to hear from you there soon.
                                                                   Yours truly
                                                                                     I.S.

Isaac
Dec. 15 1850 Bangor Maine, Sabbath  Dec. 15, 1850
Merrimack
Dear Antoinette

   Your letter was joyfully received. I had been expecting it for some days. It went first to Milo, and finally found me here.

I am here employed on the Bangor & Waterville, or Penobscot & Kennebec Rail Road. I have no permanent arrangements made. But the Directors Company, newly organized, in great haste to complete a Location this Month, in order to secure their Charter, applied to me to take hold and help finish the Location. So I did. They set me to make a Location into the City of Bangor, and I have been about it with a large party for a week past. It is perhaps about the most difficult thing to be done upon the whole line. However I have the advice of the other Engineers, so I shall be in no danger of getting all the credit, if I succeed. I do not know what permanent arrangements will be made probably none till after this month. Perhaps I have about as good chance for getting some permanent employment on the Line as most of the many who are now temporarily employed, or who are applicants. But I shall probably know nothing about it until next month.
I was very glad to hear that you are fairly at
Completed

School. I presume that the School is a very good one, and that you will enjoy yourself finely.
Mr. Charles Temple, who preached at Milo last summer, and of whom I think I wrote you, was a believe, an assistant teacher at Merrimack a while, and I have heard him speak highly of the School and of Mr. Russell. It must be very pleasant for you having your brother with you. Both will enjoy it better. I shall want to hear whether you have got a convenient and agreeable Boarding Place, and also how you continue to like the school and the studies you pursue. How many pleasures there are in school life. I do not know but I should like to go back and live over again some of my school days. though I make it my rule not to look back much.

 You ask my advice about your studies. I think my advice will be not to study too much; above all be careful of health, enter freely into society, if there is that which is really good and refined;  recreate and enjoy yourself as well as improve your mind  We are of compound natures and various capacities, and all our powers should be duly cultivated the mind by study, the body by exercise, the heart and the manners by communion with God and our fellow beings. I suppose an attention to health is one of the first of duties; without health we can enjoy none of the blessings of God, and yet how apt we are to neglect it in the pursuit of other things.
Completed

My Sister we hope is getting along well, though rather slowly, yet gained health & strength constantly. My brother I fear is getting worse instead of better, he seems to be slowly losing what little strength he has left.

I have been extremely busy this week past both day and evening: so I have very little leisure to see my friends, yet it seems quite pleasant to be near them only. I think I may enjoy it if I can get employment here for a while.

Well I must stop writing or not go to Church this evening. I shall hope to hear from you again very soon, and all about your school etc.

                                                                             Yours sincerely
                                                                                       I.S. Metcalf
